Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a splint and wrap it around the end of the radius, and pour medicine into the splint and insert the radius with the splint into the tube from above, until the splint adheres to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do that many times, until you obtain what you wish regarding the cautery of the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then release it: for indeed it will dry out and fall off after three days or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	But if you desire to repeat the medication, repeat it; and after cauterization wipe around the wound with a cloth soaked in butter, and clean with it what is in the surrounding area from medicine, and wash with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And care for it outwardly with ointments, and inwardly with gargles, until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Therefore this kind of cure is more wholesome than an incision and farther removed from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the wound is cured even with something that is more subtle than a cautery and an incision: it is cured with fumigation, in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calaments, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and jasmine, and chamomile, and abrotan, and similar things to them from herbs: and gather all of them together, or some of them in a pot, and they are submerged with vinegar, and boil: and the pot is smeared with clay decently: and there is a hole in the middle of the pot, above which an instrument is made concave in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made from silver or copper. And introduce the extremity in which is a stone into the mouth of the invalid until the vapor ascends to the uvula above the cannula until the uvula is obscured much.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then pour over it many times until it becomes cool.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware lest you make this cure at the beginning of an ulcer's arrival.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it frequently adds to the ulcer and you should not do that unless at a turning away of its heat.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not present to you, then take a reed and mix in its extremity the skin of an egg so that the mouth of the invalid does not burn, for the skin of an egg prevents vapour from burning the mouth: and this is a good cure with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the removal of thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter Thirty-eight.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times something sticks to the throat, either a fishbone or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore you must extract what appears above from which sight falls after pressing the tongue with an instrument under the sun and it is declared to you that it is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary that you make the invalid vomit before food has digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps indeed something attached will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the invalid swallows a piece of dried turnip or a piece of lettuce root or he swallows a small dry piece of bread or takes a piece of dried seaweed and binds it with string then he swallows it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it comes to the place where are thorns or bones and is extracted, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	Therefore if it does not come out with what we said, then use a lead instrument according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be a wooden stick thicker than a forearm for a short distance, and let there be a bend at its end, so that it may easily enter the throat: and let this itself have its head raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware of touching his epiglottis with it, lest he should cough, and push with it the jawbone, or the spine, or let the physician insert himself by hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But what the sick person should insert is better, that is, according to his knowledge of the place where the thing appertaining thereto is situated: and let him push it down or draw his hand with the instrument upwards, all that in proportion as it was prepared for him, until it come out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	About the removal of a leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is treated with what I said in the section on cure with medicines, and it does not yield, then consider within the throat of the sick man before the sun, or at the sun after you have pressed his tongue with the instrument that I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If then your sight falls on the leech, draw it out with a small hook, or with delicate tweezers decently.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	And if it is not possible with them: then take a concave cannula and insert it into the throat of the sick man as far as near the throat; then insert into the concavity of the cannula iron glowing with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do that many times, and let the sick person abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take the vomit full of cold water, and open his mouth in it; and let him swallow his mouth with it, and not swallow anything from it: and let him move the water one hour after another with his own hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For indeed the leech immediately drops off when it feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not come out with what we have told, then fumigate the sick person with camphor, or with asbestos, with the instrument that I told you about in fumigating a cleft palate.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that many times, since it will fall itself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in burning is thus: take a pot, in which live branches are with fire; and let the pot be covered with a cover, through whose middle there is an opening; and place the end of the instrument within that opening.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then cast the burning onto it and let the patient place his mouth at the end of the pipe and close his mouth so that the burning does not go out until you know that the burning has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	Which if it does not fall, then repeat the burning many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the patient endure thirst, and eat salt, and onions, and drink no water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he exit with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which a leech is drawn from the throat when it falls upon itself in sight.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to pincers, as you see, except that it has this curve which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the beak of a bird which is called a stork, in which there is roughness of the bill; when it catches something, it does not let it go entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of apostumes and their sectioning and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	The kinds of apostumes are many and various according to their remembrance, namely one or two in this book; and they differ in the making of holes in them and in cutting them out from two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of which is a kind of aposteme in itself, and because it contains moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second method is on account of the places, in which it occurs from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an aposteme occurring on the head is another thing from a aposteme occurring in the anus; and an aposteme occurring in a fleshy place is another thing from a aposteme occurring at joints; and each of them has its own judgment according to treatment.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from abscesses there are those which should not be perforated unless after maturation of the pus in them, and its complement: and from these there are those which should be perforated while they are raw, and do not mature according to the complement.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Just as abscesses that are close to joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs close to a joint and continues until it corrupts what is around it, the ligaments or nerves of that joint are perhaps corrupted: wherefore there is a cause more near to the contraction of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an abscess in a principal member: for if you delay its perforation until it matures, it will harm either the principal member itself or through that principal member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is close to the anus, therefore perforate it unripe: and it should not be that you perforate raw abscesses, not of complete digestion, unless what is close to the anus, lest it putrefies deeply and extends to the interior parts of the anus, and makes a fistula, or remains in its end which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the hour of perforating an abscess that has matured according to its complement: and it is a time for rest from pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness and pulse, and sharpness of the head of the abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you should do the same perforation in the lower place of the abscess and more prominent elevation: and let the perforation go lengthwise with the body, if abscesses are in parts of hands and feet, and places of elbows, tendons, nerves, arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflux.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which are reflected, go with the perforation according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	But when the abscess is in fleshy places: then it is better to delay its perforation until its digestion is confirmed, just as we said according to its complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Since if you perforate it before that, the course of the disease will be prolonged from it, and there are many foulness and stench, and perhaps its lips will become hardened, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain pustules are perforated according to the breadth of the body for necessity, or according to what that member needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small perforation in small pustules and a large perforation in large ones; or multiple sections according to the likeness of the size of the pustule.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are pustules from which the skin must be cauterized and when it has been made like a cloth and has reached its end, so that it is already dead, as with those that occur in many places, such as carbuncles and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from them are cut those which have a three-sided section.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from them is that, from which it is cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Just as an inguinal pustule.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from them are those in which a round section is administered and a lunar section, and similar ones from sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That however does not have a head, such as soft and superficial pustules, it is necessary to perforate it with a superficial or flat perforation.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the pustule is thick and has already gathered a lot of pus, and you perforate it, so that you do not hasten and draw out all the pus at once; rather, draw out a part of it from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then apply an ointment to the pustule until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to measure, until it comes out. Especially if the patient is weak in vigor, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old decrepit person; for the spirit of life often dissolves from the animal with the exit of pus, and perhaps the sick person will die, and you do not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore be careful with this chapter, great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your incision, by which you make an opening in the pustules, it is necessary to clean the wound; and pay attention.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	So if the wound of the pustule is small or flat, then apply a linen bandage, or an old cloth.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the pustule is great and there are many openings of the incision, it is necessary then that you insert linen into all the openings until they come together.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you cut a part of the skin on the pustule or hollowed it out in its surroundings: then you must fill it with an old cloth, or as when one weaves fabric, or is cleansed with linen wool without moisture: and bind it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it off, and care for it with what is necessary from the ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if there should occur a flow of blood at the hour of your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after a cloth is soaked in them; and put it on top of the place of the bleeding many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flow of blood persists, then it is necessary that you administer remedies, and treatments, and powders, which I have narrated in many places of this our book, and from division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the time of winter, and the place of the pustule is many nerves: then it is necessary that you pour poultices with wine and hot oil: and put them on the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer, and the places are fleshy: then it is necessary that you put poultices soaked in water and oil, or with wine and oil, and all of that cool.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until when it will be the third day, as we said, then it is necessary that you dissolve the pustule and clean it, and administer to its cure what is fitting for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from knowledge of curing abscesses in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method however of distinction, I have already spoken about every abscess, how there is a way for its cure chapter by single chapter.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Concerning the cutting out of abscesses that occur on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Abscesses occur on the skin of the head that are small and are like boils which are contained within a covering that is like a sack around them: as if they themselves were hens' eggs.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds or types are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are the fatty ones, and among them are those which contain a moisture similar to mud: and among them are those which contain a moisture similar to jellies and puddings: and like things, and among them are those which are hard and stony.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the cutting out of all of them, and in their extraction there is no fear, as long as an artery does not get in the way at the time of their incision.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation for cutting them out is that you try them with an instrument, the shape of which comes after this, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then cut it out with an incision following the length of the abscess, according to a superficial cut in this shape.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with an incision from the line b to the line g. With however the moisture evacuated, then scrape out the sac that contains it, and let nothing of it be left whatever.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times indeed it returns, if anything remains from it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the cut in Egyptian ointment, if it is present, and if not, in water and salt: and fill with it the wound, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For indeed it will dissolve what remains from the sac.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then again draw over it a second time with Egyptian ink the third time and if you need that, until you are confident that nothing will remain of the abscess. Then care for the wound with ointment until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the abscess contains a thickened nodule then cut it according to this form with an incision shaped like a cross; and throw some woolen threads between the arms of the incision, and scrape away all of it from every part; and try your skill in extracting the skin that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if an artery makes difficulty for you, then do what I will tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly act with the abscess if it is stony, from cutting and treating it in the same way, according to what we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And a cut over a stony abscess is easier because it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes such abscesses are found on the head of some people in which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	For I cut over an abscess on the head of an elderly woman and found the abscess like a solid, hard, rough, white stone which could not be broken; and if anyone struck it with force, throwing at it, he would wound himself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	However in other abscesses that occur on the head, apart from those which occur on the heads of children and at the roots of the ears, a cut over them all is a superficial incision.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make an opening in them from the lower part upwards to ease the flow of pus downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for them with that which suits them according to the treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	About cutting off Swellings in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur in the neck and under the armpits and in the groin, and sometimes also in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And above those which happen on the neck, there is one and many, generated from one another: and every boil is within its own skin, as it is with nodes and abscesses of the head, as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the types of these boils are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from them indeed there are stony ones, and from them there are those that contain moisture, and from them are malignant ones which do not obey treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, when you see one of good condition in touch, which is clearly close in color to the skin and moves in every part, and is not attached with nerves of the neck, nor with veins, nor with arteries, nor is it deep: you should cut it out by a superficial incision from the upper part towards the lower part of the body along line b. to line g., and scrape it clean on all sides: and stretch two flaps of skin with a hook or with many hooks if necessary, as we said about the abscesses of the head, and pull it out slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And beware lest you cut the vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let your knife be not very sharp: lest it should cause you to injure yourself with the cut or annoy the patient and you should cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you should cut a vein or an artery, or it prevents you from operating, then put powdered eggshell or some powders that stop blood into the wound and bind the wound, and leave it until the sharpness of the boil subsides and the wound becomes soft: or it begins to want to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is stopped by its own skin. Therefore return to your operation until you have completed it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then check with your index finger if anything remains of other small boils: therefore cut them out and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein at the root of the boil, then you must not cut out that boil from its root: rather it should be tied with a strong double thread and left until it falls off on its own without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with a cord of elder tree, which I have previously immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for him.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If a navel string is cut off completely, then it is necessary to sew the lips of the wound together, and leave him immediately once you see that there is no excess left.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess remaining because of the largeness of the navel string, then it is necessary to take pains to cut out its root and extract it, and to administer the suture which we mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what of the umbilical cords that contain moisture, pierce it with a shallow puncture so that you can see its place of maturity, and make the puncture from above down towards the lower part of the body, as we mentioned.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the puncture licinia with ointment and similar things to it, so that they eat away what remains from corruption, until you see that the wound is now cleansed; then care for him with generating flesh ointment, until he heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Of the cutting of the epiglottis from an abscess occurring within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said this cutting of the epiglottis was to be done, and I have not seen anyone on our land who has done it; and this is the writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	However, in those who have dropsy, it is necessary to avoid the cutting of the epiglottis, since there would be no benefit from it, because all the veins and the lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a warm abscess in the mouth or throat or on both tonsils, when there is no pain in the channel, it is necessary to cut the epiglottis so as to escape from destruction which comes from obstruction.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is therefore necessary when we wish to do this that we cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small section through its breadth, in what is between two circles by quantity, so that the cut is in the mucous membrane, not in the cartilage; and this place is indeed suitable for cutting, because it is secluded from flesh and the vessels of blood are far away.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then it is necessary that he stretch out the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he sews up the skin until it reaches the canal; blood will ooze out if he sees anything coming from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he makes an incision as we have said; and it signifies the cutting of the canal from the phlegm that comes out of it, with the bursting and cutting of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the open wound for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour that is feared of suffocation has passed, bring together the two lips of the wound of skin and its own self alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines which make flesh grow, until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	He says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this speech which we have narrated is that it is not an incision unless they see that some of these abscesses has already ulcerated the throat of the infirm person: and the infirm person has been elevated to death, and wants his breath cut off: they go to cutting the Epiglottis, so that the infirm person may breathe over the place of the wound with a certain respiration, and be saved from death: and for this reason they have ordered to leave the open wound, until the malice of the illness is consumed, and its malice is three days, and almost like itself: then therefore they have ordered to sew up the wound, and cure it, until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And what I have seen through myself is that one servant took a knife and sent it into her own throat, and cut with it part of the canal of the lungs.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure her, and I found her groaning, as is the groan of a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	So I therefore pulled out from the wound and found very little blood that had come out of the wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore I am confident that it itself had not cut off the vein nor closed it: and wind was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I took hold of it therefore and my own wound, and I cured it until it was well: and nothing happened to the maid servant, except that she coughed with a hoarse voice: and she returned after some days in a better condition.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say, that in the section of the epiglottis there is no fear.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	About the cutting of an obstruction of the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This called hernia of the throat, is a great swelling, according to the colour of the body, and it is very much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either it is natural, or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural one certainly there is no skill.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental one however is according to two modes: of which one is similar to a knot of sinew.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode, is similar to a swelling that occurs from the constriction of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And within it there is fear, and it should not be approached with iron, unless it is small: and you prove it, and investigate it with a probe.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	So if you find it similar to a knot of sinew, and it is not suspended with any veins: then cut it, as knots are cut: and bring it out with what contains it from the sac, if it is in a sac: and if not, then thoroughly examine all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then cure the place with that which is necessary from treatment, until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	About cutting over the shape of Knots.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already said all their kinds in the division: and it is necessary that I narrate here the difference between a knot and an exitus, since it causes doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that when the flux is hot and there is fever and great pains until the ebullition of superfluity ceases and putrefaction is completed: then indeed fever and heat abate.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	For if there is no heat, nor fever, nor pain, and they contain the knots of sifachin, which are their special pouches, and correspond to the color of the body: and their openings are like chickpeas, and they swell like pomegranates, and larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either swollen: or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of the moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to the treatment of a Knot, you must examine it and inquire into itself first with an instrument which is called an Intromissum, according to its shape as described in the chapter that follows.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the manner of inquiry into all suppurations and Knots is this: that you take this instrument and insert it into a more moist place which you find in the supuration: and then turn your fingers with it gradually, until you know that the instrument has already pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then use your last finger according to the measure of the size of the supuration.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum and observe what comes out behind it.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore clear moisture comes out, whatever the colour may be: then cut it off with a superficial incision, as I said of other suppurations.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture comes out in the wake of the Intromissum, then know that it is fatty: so cut above it with an incision having the form of a cross, as I taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and remove the skin from all around with ease: and guard the pouch if possible over it, so that you may extract the healthy one along with the Knot.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the abscess bursts during an operation, and it is not possible to extract the healthy part itself, it often happens that this occurs, then extract it in bits until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if something remains from it a little or much, the knot returns according to most cases.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Which if it overpowers you, and something remains from it: then fill the wound at your completion with certain corrosive powders sharp as knives: and bind the wound, and place above it what sits an abscess warm, and take care of it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	Since therefore the knot is large, then bind its two lips, and take care of it with what covers it.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if there is for you a contrary vein pulsating or not pulsating then hasten and fill the place with crushed zygite and let it be tight for two days, or three, until the wound putrefies and blood ebullition quiets down: then return to cutting what remains from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	About external instruments for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of forceps, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For from them is the large one, and from them is the middle one, and from them is the small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be made of iron with four sharp corners arranged in a circle, so that they may quickly enter into an abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of perforators, and no, that is, they pierce: and one of them is called beris, that is, piercing: and there are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For from them is the large one, and the middle one, and the small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They convene so that through them abscesses, and ulcers, and fistulas, and boils may be investigated from what is between them from bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made rounded, smooth, and fine, such as the large needles with which benches are furnished, from citron wood, or from air, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And those made from citron wood are better among them.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And they are also made by experience from black lead, which suit for the examination of fistulas, whose concavity are reflections, so that they may be reflected with their softness along with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again there are three kinds of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because they are long from among them, and the middle ones, and the short ones, according to the quantity of the width of a fistula and its stricture.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of ligatures, and they are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because there are simple ones, namely with one bend: and they are of three kinds as you see, Great, Middle, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are blind ligatures: and they are of three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are ligatures having two bends, and they are of three kinds: and there are ligatures having three bends, and they are of three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which knots and apostemes are cut and scraped away: and they are of three kinds: because from them is great, middle, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which the section is made are sharp, the other extremities are not sharp: and they are not placed thus, unless so that with them a wound may be given in the scarring of knots at the fear of cutting a vein or nerve: and so the infirm man may be healed by them, and find tranquility for a little time from the burning which he finds at the scarring of an aposteme.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magdas, and they are of three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made from air and resemble a quill with which ink is made: and at the wider end there is a hidden point of bronze: and it runs to the inside and outside as you wish, just as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the hidden bronze needles which are kept between fingers for puncturing boils and they cannot be felt by the sick person, and there are three kinds, great, middle, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the windlasses with which bleeding is stopped: and they are of three kinds, great, middle, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They should be made from air or bronze, rounded in shape, somewhat long as you see, and fine in subtlety.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary for you to have these kinds of windlasses with you, the great and small ones, so that you can bleed with speed when necessity arises, and then when medical treatment is not present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But you should not use them for bleeding in every place of the body, and you should not use them except in fleshy places: such as on the arms of the legs, and the hips, and the arms of the shoulders, and breasts, and belly, and groin, and similar places made of fleshy, moist skin.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they are made into small instruments similar to the rinds of figs, according to their shape, with which blood is let out when it flows from a place of venesection, or at an incision in a vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made round in this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	About the treatment of swellings in men which resemble breasts in women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men swell up at the time of sleep (that is, when they start to be polluted in their sleep) until they resemble female breasts and remain as foul boils.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore whoever shuns that, ought to cut over the breasts with a lunar incision, according to this shape from the line, b to the line, g. Then he should scrape off the fatty substance altogether.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with a concoction of boiled flesh.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and take care of it, until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the nipple declines to the lower part and becomes flabby on account of its size, as happens in women: then it is necessary that it be cut into two upper sides of itself with two incisions similar in figure to a crescent moon, each of which contains the other at their ends until there is a line greater containing the lesser, according to this shape from line b to line g. Then scrape off the skin which is between the two lips and remove the fatty substance, and administer what we said about suture and powder, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you are unable to complete the incision as it is necessary for you to cut, on account of the disturbance of the sick person or on account of a flowing of blood: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with a moistened ointment corrosive and let it be, until it corrodes what remains from the fatty substance.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it, until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	About the puncturing of an apostema, which occurs under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemas which occur under the nipple are of the kind of strophulae hard, which contain cysts, and among them are those that contain moistures.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore those that are among them which contain moistures, it is necessary to cut them with a lunar incision, according to this shape, from line b to line g. And when therefore everything in the apostema has been evacuated through pus, then fill it with old coagulated matter and let it be until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the splint is taken away, and it is treated with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	And if there is an abscess of the type known as strophulae, then cut over it as we said in the treatment for equal sized strophulae.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound is extended so that it discharges pus, then apply a cautery to it, as we said in what was mentioned beforehand.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Concerning the cutting of an abscess which occurs because of the artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is ruptured and the skin which is over it becomes swollen, then many times an abscess occurs from this; and similarly a vein also happens to become inflamed.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it can be known that an abscess and inflammation are due to the artery and vein are: because when the abscess is caused by the artery, it is long and forms in the deep part of the body; and when you push with your fingers on the abscess, you feel a grating sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is caused by the vein is rounded in the outer part of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And cutting over this abscess is an error, and especially that which is under the armpits, and groin, and neck, and in many places of the body, and it becomes very large.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is necessary therefore that its treatment be avoided with iron, and what also occurs in the extremities or head, it must be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, on that which occurs from the inflammation of the opening of the artery, make an incision on the skin in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with a hook, afterwards the artery; and free it from its sheaths, until it is uncovered.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert a needle under it, and make it penetrate as far as the other side, and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, just as I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries which are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place, which is between two ligaments with a spatula, until the blood that is in it altogether goes out and the abscess is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer a treatment that generates pus until the ligaments drop: afterwards take care of it with ointments suitable for it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there is an abscess due to the cutting of a vein, then you must take with your hand as much as possible from the abscess together with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place which you held with your hand, and make it penetrate; let there be within it twice as much thread as its thickness, until you take it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie with it itself the abscess with a good ligament: as I told you to tie an olive branch with two ends of thread from two sides.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread will come out, then insert another needle with another thread under the abscess all around the puncture of the needle: press and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in the middle of itself, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut off the superfluity of skin and let go that which is tied from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on top of it a poultice which you immersed in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the treatment that is made with liniments and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	¶ Of an abscess which occurs from a twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in the Artery and Vein, similarly an abscess occurs in the Nerves: which occurs in them a blow, or it occurs from excessive labor, and similar things: and it forms much in those places of joints, or heel, and in every place where joints are moved: and it is a grave abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its colour is similar to that of the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is constricted with suffocation, a weak person feels in it something like numbness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess formed deep within the body, nay, it is beneath the skin, and itself moves in every direction, and does not extend forward to the front or backward to the back.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Whatever then is located at the joints, should not be cut with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps indeed a contraction will occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is located on the head or on the forehead, make an incision with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore it is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and let it suppurate; then remove it, and join the wound together with stitches: and care for it, until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	About the cutting of an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There are some people whose bellies and other parts of their bodies often experience swellings, which are called "Fungalia", because they resemble mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is thin, and whose head is thick, and their lips are turned inward.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is a small one among them, and there is a great one that swells very much.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I myself have already seen a man, and in his abdomen there were two swellings that resembled mushrooms more than other things; there was no difference between them, they were white, small roots, and their lips turned inward and were closed, and moisture flowed from them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore cut into them and found one to weigh about ten and eight unciae, and the other about six unciae. And the operation for their cutting is, as you consider then, if the patient is wet and the color of the swelling is white, moist, thin root: then make an incision on it with a wide spatula, and have cauterizing irons in your presence at the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For blood is often driven out at the point of incision: therefore hasten if blood overpowers you, then cauterize him.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see a sick person afraid and timid at the incision with iron, then take a well-made cord of lead and bind him with it; whose manner is as we said, and leave him for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the leaden string.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	So you will not cease from binding with lead, whenever it grows in thickness, until it is cut off and falls apart by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if however the root of the abscess is large and thick, then there is something to be feared and dreaded at its incision, especially when it is within the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However it is possible that you cut through half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for him, until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you presume to cut the abscess which is of a pale color, little sensation, foul appearance; for it is a cancerous ulcer: and I come with a reminder of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	About the care of an Enlargement of the Navel.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A swelling of the navel arises from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures of the navel-skin which is over the abdomen: and an intestine or a spleen comes out from it, according to as happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood flowing from the vein, or from the artery, according to what was previously said.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a constriction of the windpipe that is closed within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is because of a fissure of the navel-skin and an exit for the intestines: then its color is similar to the color of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and its shape appears different.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to protrusion of the intestine, then its position will be, as we have said, of a more violent difference.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	Therefore, when you press it with your fingers, it becomes hidden; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it greatly swells at the entrance of the bath, and the effort is violent.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is due to moisture, it is soft, then it does not become hidden when you press it with your hand, nor does it shrink or swell.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Which if it is due to blood, then with these signs an abscess appears towards blackness of the scab.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to born flesh: then there is a serious abscess, large, hard, and it remains according to the size of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is indeed due to inflammation, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on it is, as you consider then, if the swelling of the navel is due to blood of an artery, or vein, or inflammation: then it is necessary that you refrain from its cure.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that there is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter in which I said abscesses due to an artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	Which if the swelling of the navel is due to the intestine or theomentum: then it is necessary that you command the patient to hold his breath and stand upright straight.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with encaustum around the entire navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to be placed on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a bandage, wide enough, around the navel over the place you marked with encaustum.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the abscess towards above, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him strongly around in a circle with thread or with a cord of linen tied firmly: and let the knot be tightened.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open up the middle of the swelling which is extended above the tendon.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you have found it already captured by the tendon: then pull out the foreign body, and insert the index finger into it, and push the intestine towards the interior of the belly: and if you find a splinter, then take it up with forceps, and cut off its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if there is against you an artery, or a vein: then encircle it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads: and insert two needles into the ligature which you made around the swelling in the shape of a cross, so that they penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tie the swelling in four places over the needles: and if you wish, remove the needles, and leave the place until the extended flesh putsrefies: and falls on its own: or cut it when it becomes tender and putrefies.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with what is necessary from ointments, until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the protrusion of the navel is from putrid flesh within it, or from moisture: then you must concave the swelling, as we said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out the blood, or moisture, which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of it with what solidifies the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	About the cure OF CANCEr.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken about the kinds of Cancer and how to cure it with medicines: and we warned against it being cured with iron lest it become ulcerated: and we spoke about Cancer generated in the womb, and the precaution against its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes a Cancer is in a place where its removal is possible: such as a Cancer which is on the nipple or on the thigh, and similar ones which are located on removable parts of the body: especially when it is beginning to be small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it becomes old and large, you should not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I myself could not heal anyone from it, nor have I seen another before me who has succeeded in reaching it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we said, is, as was previously stated, to precede and dissolve the diseased part with black henna sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find a bleeding with evident filling.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the diseased part by preparation, where it will be located during the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then insert into the cancer the needles that suit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then concave it from all sides with the skin, according to investigation, until nothing remains of its roots: and let the blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, but rather express the places, and wipe away the thick blood entirely by hand, or with what is possible there from instruments.
