A multitude of physicians therefore treated him for about two years and none of them was wise in the art of hands until I was called, and I saw his leg and the matters which were flowing from those openings with a great current: even all of his body had already become blackened, and its color was yellowish.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore inserted my probe into one of the openings of the places, and the probe came up to the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings: and I found that they were communicating with one another from all parts of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I therefore approached and cut above one of those openings until I uncovered a part of the bone: and I found it corrupted, which had already been eaten away, blackened, rotten, and perforated, until it had penetrated to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I therefore cut out what was shown to me, and prepared it from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I removed that which would not have been in the bone unless the corruption which I cut out.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And now I had rooted it out.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I put the wound's restoration with consolidating medicines for a long time.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it has not been consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried again, and uncovered a second part of the bone above the first discovery: and I found a continued corruption with the bone: and I cut out what appeared to me from that corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempted its restoration.
Et non est restauratum.	And it has not been restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	So I uncovered it again, and did not stop cutting into the bone little by little, and attempting its restoration: and it was not restored, until I cut out from the bone about the width of a hand, and extracted that with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored him with medicines, and he was soon consolidated and healed. And this repetition of the operation on him, and his incision, was not necessary unless because of the weakness of the sick man's constitution, and the scarcity of his tolerance, and my fear for him of death: since it happened to him every hour from excess of bad evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore healed with entire healing. And flesh hard as bone grew in the place of the bone, and a good condition was made in his body, and his strength returned to him. He recovered his faculties and went about without any hindrance or injury at all.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone in the place of the body is already broken: then it is necessary that you should suture it, in this way: and thus: take a tendon, and tie it at the end of the prominent bone: and have someone extend it upwards. And place another ligament of thicker wool over the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then tie it above the flesh which is over the bone: and extend its end so that you will draw the flesh downwards: and have him expose the flesh on top of the place which you wish to suture, so as not to hurt the suture.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood or a board under the bone lower down in a convenient place: because when you do this, it does not prevent the flesh from becoming corrupted.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the suture be above the place of corruption for a short while, so that there may not be concavity in the bone from corruption, and it does not appear to the senses in its appearance, and causes another suture instead of itself.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is corrupted and not prominent, rather it continues a part with another part, and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in one of its parts: then remove all flesh from around it.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood underneath.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards, suture it from the first part where there is corruption, until the suturing continues from the other part; and let the second suturing be according to length for a short while, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If there is corruption in a joint, cut out the corrupted joint and saw through the bone where it connects on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	And if indeed there is corruption in the connection of two joints, then there is no remedy for it except scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If there is corruption in the breast of the hand or in the breast of the foot; then the condition in it is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	Indeed you must inquire about the corruption and see how it appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it off, and clean it out according to whatever arrangement is possible for you, and with whatever ingenuity it heals itself in your case; when it does not bring you a contradiction of the Vein, or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that knives and saws for cutting these bones are many, according to the location of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and magnitude, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare the appropriate instrument for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you about the type of instrument which you need, when with you is a long study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the ways of this art is testimony to the ways of ailments; then indeed you will already find through yourself what suits him from instruments for every infirmity.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter's number of instruments which you will put examples above on which you cut, and proof by which you will try on others.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of a saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of a saw drawn, may it be well done.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper curve be an arc, its sharpness from iron: and its handle from boxwood, and let it be a pyramid shape well done.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of the razor for joining (parts).
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be according to the shape of the head of a star-shaped awl; and its points shall be according to the shape of the points of al-ishlyafī.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless their heads are rubbed with it when they become corroded or a large and great bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The shape of the larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The shape of the middle razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The shape of the broad razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape of the razor which has concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape of another very fine razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of a curved edge razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of a small, very fine tapered razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of the razor with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape also of the large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	It resembles a saw, and its edge is like a file: it is shown in many places for cutting bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of the razor which suits the cutting of things that have been perforated from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its edge is triangular, with sharp points.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made in India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly it should be that all the things which we have said are to be made from razors, and files, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On cutting edges, and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities are putrid either from an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have been medicated for that corruption and the cure does not take place: and you see corruption occur in a member which is not relieved by anything else: then it is necessary to cut out that member as far as the corruption follows, so that the sick person may escape through it from death or a greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that occurs to it is, that the member becomes blackened until it rots: that fire burns it or it puttrefies after blackening: until the putrefaction is cut into as far as the part that follows the member, and spreads through the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, proceed with the incision of it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the strike of some venomous things: such as the sea scorpion, and viper, and centipede, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption or the strike is in the tip of a finger, then cut off the finger and do not give space to the corruption, so that it may spread up to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it occurs in the hand, then cut off the arm from the wrist, and do not give space to the corruption, until it reaches into the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades within it, then cut off the arm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption passes through and you see him around the elbow: then the patient is at death's door.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer anything else besides that in the treatment, is the amount of worthlessness.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do this with the foot, when corruption invades a finger, then cut off the finger at one of its joints: and if it reaches into the heel of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	But if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no ingenuity in it, except release and leaving the sick person to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting a limb or sawing it is, to tighten the ligaments below where you wish to cut, and then tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And have the assistant stretch one ligament down to the lower part, and stretch another ligament up above.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments with a spatulum, or a wide-bladed instrument, until all the flesh is uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it must be cut or split.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth over all parts, and the saw not touch a sound part; lest an additional injury befall the patient, or a warm gangrene form.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if a flow of blood should occur within while you are working, then cauterize the place quickly; or put on top of it some purging powders which stop bleeding.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your dressing until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded member with a suitable bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to a man on his foot, the same thing that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is that a blackness occurred on his foot, with burning that resembles the combustion of fire; and the corruption at first occurred in his toe, until it began to spread throughout his whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man made a proper incision for himself, after he saw the corruption spreading into the member with his madness of pain and burning of it; and he cut it off at the joint, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed over him, the same corruption occurred to him in the finger of his hand on his index.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me and I attempted to recover the excess with him using what I put on his hand from medicines after purifying his body; and the excess did not become inflamed, but began to spread into another finger, until corruption occurred in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called upon me to cut off his hand and I did not wish to do it, hoping that the inflammation of the excess might subside; and I also feared death for him at the time of making an incision in his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the man's strength was beyond his control.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Therefore since he had given up hope of me, he returned to his land; and he came back to me about it, because he was in a hurry, and fell with his whole hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account unless it would be an aid concerning that which falls under the category of this affliction: and so that there may be a signification by means of which it may be indicated, and according to which it should be treated.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of fistulas, and the quality of purging with medications.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in some fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or becomes perforated and what was within it comes out by way of pus, and the place remains empty like a container: and the skin which is over it is like a cloth that has been worn thin: and it does not come to an end in its corruption, nor does it impinge on the bone, nor on the nerve, nor on the ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus: and it is not called a Fistula: but if its space is prolonged until the corruption presses upon something of these members, then it is called a Fistula, or sinus.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its treatment is to cut off the entire skin like it comes apart: and especially when it has become worn thin and made like a cloth: and you rely on it because it will not stick together with the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will stick together and it does not happen because of that last corruption following, and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh: then treat it with a purging catheter: and this is how you should consider it as being for a Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul smell: then purge it with an Egyptian medicine, which is equal parts of vinegar, oil, and galena, which are gathered together in a vessel: and they are cooked over the fire until the medicine reddens: and comes to the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need; and dissolve it with water and honey, and irrigate the navel with it: and tighten its opening, and leave medicine in it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: do this for so many days until the navel is cleansed and the foul odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes irrigate it with water of ashes, when this medicine is not present to you: and take the ash of vine wood, or of ilex trees: and pour water over it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then wash it with wine, and irrigate it with it until you have confidence that the navel is already washed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the patient is not tolerant of the Egyptian medicine, nor water of ashes, then irrigate it with a mixture of water and honey, to which something has been added from ground verdigris.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or irrigate it with a mixture of honey and wine, because from the property of honey is to cleanse and wash: and wine makes the navel adhere, especially when there is excess of bitterness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this several times and have confidence that the corruption of the navel is now removed: then irrigate it with what makes flesh grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is to take from diaphrenic plaster and dissolve it with rose oil and bitter wine: or irrigate it with certain medicines and other ointments, the properties of which I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the opening of the navel is too narrow, so that it does not take a syringe of clister: then enlarge it with a little iron: or place in it a linen cloth wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or in balsam ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is too wide, then bring together its lips with a suture: and let go from it the amount into which it will enter a syringe without an added substance.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening from which pus flows is elevated to the upper parts: then cut him in the lower place that is within it, so that pus may flow from it downward. For when pus is constricted in the depth of the Sinus, it prevents flesh from being formed there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus around its lower part as you wish: then try, that you prepare the member with a preparation by which pus may flow from it easily, as it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try, so that nothing of the pus be retained within it at all; and take consolidating medicines which are put over the mark, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it may be in communication with the whole Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut through with forceps directly into the opening of the Sinus a hole, somewhat larger than that of the Sinus itself.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from gentle ointments on another cloth according to the size of the hole; and place it over it in a position far from the opening of the Sinus, so that the pus may be alleviated from exiting from it: and do not remove the large cloth until after several days one at a time.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But that which is over the opening of the Sinus, you shall remove in every hour, so that what gathers within it from pus may come out; and so that you will know whether what comes out from it is much or little, digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when this is done again look at the place of the Sinus itself, whether its lord feels pain within it, or does not feel pain, and whether there is in it an abscess or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is stretched thus far, and you see the matter that flows out over the opening of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus has already adhered or approaches adhesion: therefore untie it in the morning, or on the third day; and when you untie the wound, then exchange another cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however the small worm issues from a sinew after a long time, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are people who retard the generation of flesh in their wounds, and those who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however it issues from a sinew after many days with undigested pus, then you will know that the sinew is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	Therefore if the adhesion of the sinew is delayed and its process prolonged, then you should add to it the drying of medicines; indeed doctors do this, so that they be wet in substance and dry in virtue: just as the unguent called diaphrenicon, when an excess of addition from rose is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And the most ultimate thing for its cure is that you should take diaphrenicon ointment and dissolve it with rose oil and sprinkle old wine equal to it in substance on top.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then bind him up with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now do similarly to this action when you don't have diaphrenicon ointment available; honey, when you cook it until it thickens and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh and aloe and frankincense; pound all of them together, and grind that on honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then bind over it a cloth, and tie it on the sinew; and bind with honey that you cooked until it thickened: and grind over it spices, and place over it a cloth, and tie him.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes administer in it Aristolochia longa, and the roots of the lily of heaven, and the lily itself is a plant, and the flour of the herb, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them either simple or compounded, pound those things, and dry the skin; and grind over honey as I told you, and use that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the swelling of a Sinus prolongs itself and is not healed by this treatment: then know that there is corruption in its depth: or it already makes an impression on the bones, or on other hard members, or ligaments: then cure it with the treatment of Fistulas, according to what was said before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	About the care of an infected fingernail and a nail that is worn down, and the addition of a cut on the finger, and a sectioning.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A Panaritium is an abscess which is born under the nail of the thumb of the hand or foot, and perhaps it is also born on other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	Therefore when the swelling prolongs itself and is neglected in its treatment and an abscess forms which is hot: or it corrupts and sends forth pus, until it corrupts the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps the corruption reaches to the bone, until there is a fetid smell from it: and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you cure it, with what we said in the division, and your treatment does not help: then it is necessary for you to cut out with a knife all the superfluity which remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For cauterization is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If however the bone is sound and also the nail is healthy, and the additions of the nail are empty and already compress the flesh towards the inside, and they begin to pierce it and hurt it: then it is necessary for you to place a thin probe under the angle of the nail which pierces the flesh, and drive it upwards: and cut out the flesh with facility, and put over what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, corrosives, until it is completely removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then cure that with ointments, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however corruption has already taken hold in the bone, then it is necessary to cut that bone open and remove it; for a corrupted bone is never healed so long as it remains within.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corruption and gangrene spreading in the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, following what has been previously mentioned about treating such a case.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat that part until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however an injury occurs to the nail, or a blow is received and it causes severe pain, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp instrument, such as an iron spatula, by a transverse cut from above towards the sight of it.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care that the cut does not reach the flesh which is beneath the nail, for you will make the patient suffer severe pain and it will be a cause of an addition of flesh growing in the place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then treat the place with that which calms pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger that grows in some people's hands is perhaps all fleshy and perhaps has bones within them, and perhaps there is a nail; and in some of them it grows at the joint or is born in some of the joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, that which grows in some of the joints of the finger does not move; and that which grows at the joint of the finger perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	And therefore, as for him who is all fleshy among them, his cutting is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is to cut it at its root with a broad-bladed instrument.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the cure of him whose birth is at the joint of the articulation is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Then abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	And as for him who is born at the end of the finger near the last joint, then it is necessary to cut into his flesh first with a round incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Next, saw the bone with one of those saws which are suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the consolidation that occurs among fingers together, often happens either from the birth of man, that is, it is born with him, or from the consolidation of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	It is necessary therefore to cut that consolidation, until the fingers return according to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then put licinia or cloths soaked in rose oil between them, so that they do not consolidate quickly and separate them: or put a thin plate of lead between them until the place consolidates as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if there occurs a consolidation of some fingers with the palm, then cut that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and fits the figure of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	About cutting an ulcer.
Caput XCII.	Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Uites are thickened veins which are swollen with superfluities of melancholy which occur in many parts of the body: and their event often is in legs, especially in the legs of those who travel and labour, and carry loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is necessary therefore that you administer an excursion of the body with black henna several times a strong excussion.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then let blood from the Basilica vein of the patient.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of them however with iron is according to two modes.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they be cut and the black blood be drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is to raise the vein and draw it out whole.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of it is in this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Bind the leg first with hot water a lot until the thick and bloody blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the leg of the infirm person from the upper part of his hip to the lower part of his knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three broad cuts.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then lift, that is, draw out the blood in your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and it should be as phlebotomy is done on a person first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the nail down to where it will come out with blood, until the quantity of blood which you see is sufficient and as much as the strength of the sick person can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it up and instruct him to abstain from foods that produce black bile. And let the evacuation and phlebotomy be repeated when the veins are full and that thing hurts the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The lifting of it however is in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg of the sick person if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert him into a bath or soak him in the water of his leg with hot water until it is red and the veins are swollen: or exercise him strongly if there is no bath present, until the member heats up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin directly on the vein in a long cut or at its end near the knee or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the cut with a hook and scrape out the vein from every part until it is visible to sight: and its appearance is when you see it become red towards blackish.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it flows out of the skin, you will see it white as if it were a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert under it a thread until when it is lifted up and flows out of the skin: hang it with a blind hook gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another incision near that other incision three fingers away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift it up with threads as you did and hang it up with another hook as you first did.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another incision, or several cuts, as you need it.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then lift and incise her with the last cut at the heel bone.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then draw it out to the incision that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you draw her out from the upper incision, or with all higher cuts, until she comes out completely; then make an incision.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if she does not obey you to be drawn out and lifted: then insert the forceps with a strong double thread, tie her, and draw it out; or insert under it a rod: and turn your hand in all ways until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to lift it up very much, and it will go over the patient causing a nuisance.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have drawn it out completely: then place over the place of wounds a cloth soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil; and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the tendril is contracted, having a twisting, and is wound around parts, and it is not as we said straight: then you must cut through it on all sides of its twisting, and places of its winding.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with forceps, until you lift it out completely; and beware at your cut on her that you do not cut the vein, or wound it: for it will be difficult for you over yourself to lift, or draw it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore conserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the cutting by which the tendril is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the blind forceps.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curved like the other forceps, nor is it sharp at its end, so as not to wound the vein; and it has a gentle, coarse flexibility, because if it were fine, it would cut the vein with its fineness: or rather let its coarseness be excessive, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the removal of the vein of the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter Ninety-Three.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs of warm lands, such as those of the Alizagi and the land of Arabs, and in dry, hot lands with little fertility, that is, where grass nor tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other places of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from the putrefaction which occurs beneath the skin, just as occurs in living within bodies of snakes and earthworms and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the inception of this event of the vein is that which occurs in the leg a violent inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place becomes swollen.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out from that place of swelling, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore its extremity appears from it, then you must wrap over it a piece of lead, the weight of which is half a dram, up to two drams, and tie it on: and let the lead hang from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something comes out of it to the outside, wrap that up in lead and tie it on.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	And if it should be prolonged much, then cut off a part of it, and wrap up the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut into its root before it has come out completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut into it, it becomes constricted and goes back into the flesh: and causes an abscess and putrefaction to occur in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Wherefore it is necessary to treat it gently and extract it gradually, until it comes out completely from its last part, and there remains nothing of it in the body: and from this vein something is extracted in certain people which is five palms and ten fingers long.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to my attention that a man has escaped from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If, however, you happen to be in the hour of your treatment at that time, then insert a thread into its opening and pierce it through with a long needle, along with the body, until everything inside is evacuated from it: and administer putrefaction to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then treat the same cure for ulcers or apostumes.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein indeed sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or on the foot itself; and there are formed for it many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore cure this vein as we said in the division, and along with what was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Concerning the cutting over Worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bovine affliction.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This affliction is called Bovine sickness among us, because it frequently occurs in oxen, and there is one small worm which is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it moves throughout the entire body, ascending and descending; and is shown to sensation from limb to limb, until it bursts wherever it bursts through the skin and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just like worms and snakes, that is, tapeworms, and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And fear is felt from its malignity.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it goes into the body and rises to the head, and reaches a place, then perhaps it bursts forth in it and emerges, and destroys an eye; and that often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	So when you want to cure it and extract itself, then that is not done unless during its movement and appearance to sensation.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you should tighten what is above it and what is below it with a strong tightening ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut over it, and draw it out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	And if it runs deep into the flesh, and you do not find it: then place a cautery over the place with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And what is most feared about it is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then tie under it the eyebrow with a good constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut over it and draw it out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient should be nourished with a purification of his body with dissolving medicines for bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	About the cutting over an abscess called Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter Ninety-Five.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This affliction is called in our land Nakir, and it is a pain that occurs in some members, then it passes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have already seen it, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was summoned to a sick woman in some villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm's tendon.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed I saw one swelling move with a flow, as a worm moves, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than it can, so that it is like quicksilver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore receded from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it ran to the rest of the body, until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving throughout her entire body, just as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I have looked therefore at the speed of its transference from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed I myself had not seen this affliction with my own eyes in such a way as is according to this method.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However I have seen many who find the pain to be transferred from member to member and not see it with their eyes as I did see it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it is anything other than the fact that the woman was among those who have been discovered to have dry bodies and detected veins from them, hence it becomes apparent to sense that this inflammation has been transferred.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary for them not to appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	So when you wish to treat it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is appearing to your eye as we said, tie above it and below it quickly, and cut above it until that inflamed vein bursts out: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then treat it by a bodily cleansing and by means of that which repels inflamed veins, and crush them with fetid pills and with pills made from sapan wood and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter Ninety-Six.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are different according to their kinds and according to the places in which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	And their difference is, because there are some that have large points and small ones: and bent and straight.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are some which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from them that are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from them that are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those however which fall according to the limbs on which they fall, is according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For indeed members are from principal convex members, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and similar things to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore an arrow falls into some of these members and the signs of death appear to you, which I tell you after, then it is necessary that you take out the extraction of the arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then take it out and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For the signs of the brain are these when an arrow falls into it and penetrates the bone and comes out through the siphac which is above the brain: since there occur from it a severe headache, dimness, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, and confusion of intellect, and vomiting of cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will come out through the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And a white moisture similar to mud comes out from the place of the wound.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it flows from it like the moisture of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment and remove the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple: and it feels with it as if it itself were fixed in a hard thing, not in an empty thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the arrow is similar to the movement of the pulse: and blood black flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows that coldness of extremities, and cold sweat, and numbness.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore, that death is certainly approaching.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is the exit of bloody froth from the wound. And the vessels which follow the neck become inflamed and change in color of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he exhales a great, high breath: and he seeks to attract cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	Which if the arrow should fall into the pleura that is in the chest then it is near to the small ribs and a great gasping with very severe pain with a sigh and all the members of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach then perhaps something undigested will issue from the wound out of food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the intestine and is fixed there then something of feces will issue from the wound or dung or an intestine which has already been torn apart.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope in his cure nor in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	Which if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine issues from it and something proceeds from it to the outer parts and a more severe pain is over the patient then you should know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The other parts however such as the face and neck and throat and shoulder and rib and hip and knee and like members are saved according to many dispositions when the arrow does not find an artery or a nerve and is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen of these arrow wounds so that you may understand by it about your own cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is that an arrow fell into the root of the eyelash of a certain man, in the lacrimal eye.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from the other side of him, under the fat of his ear and he was healed and no harm occurred to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew which had fallen into the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid and the arrow was already hidden and I did not succeed to draw out anything except a small piece of it with which it adhered to its wood and it was a great arrow among the arrows of the Turkish bows, with a soft iron tip, in which there are no barbs.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew was healed, and no evil occurrence happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, and that one is the one with ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore bound above it between two splints: and now it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I manipulated with it, therefore, until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man that had fallen into his belly: and we thought he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Since then thirty days have passed for him, and nothing has changed for him from his conditions, I bound above the arrow: and I manipulated on it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no evil occurrence happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw the man to whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound was hardened over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Since then it has been seven years, the arrow came out from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw the woman to whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound was hardened over it, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing changed for her from her conditions, and the woman did not find any harm from any of her natural movements.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen into his face: and the wound was hardened, and it remained, not finding him much pain: and similar things happened to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the king's princes, which had fallen into his middle nose and was already declining to the right side a little: and the arrow was hidden totally.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called for his treatment after the fall of the arrow until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found then a wound from the arrow tightly constricted.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	He therefore examined it with a fine needle, and did not feel it; and he himself found the puncture and pain under his own ear from the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore believed that the puncture was from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore applied a plaster to the place where there was a drawing and digestive virtue, trusting to myself that the place would suppurate and that I would see a sign of the arrow, so that I could cut over it; and this did not occur in the place which occurs when an arrow has struck the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore applied the plaster over him for many days and the accident did not occur, and the wound became consolidated in the meantime; and he remained sick from its extraction for a space of days until he felt the arrow one day inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore applied a sharp and corroding medicine to the wound for many days until it was opened; and when I examined him with a probe and felt the tip of the arrow which adhered to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	I then added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until it became visible to us that the tip of the arrow appeared; and a period of time passed with him for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move them and it did not yield to exit: then I did not cease to file and invent over it with the devices of my ingenuity, until one day I began to work on it with well-made forceps, according to the shape that their handles come to in the end, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed the doctors judge that the nasal cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore restored it and the wound became consolidated and the sick man was completely healed with a whole health; and nothing harmed him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: as to place a rule and sign on that which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and its distinctions cannot be comprehended with narration; nor can it be comprehended by that book, and a wise craftsman compares a little with much: and what is present with what is absent; and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument in the descent of foreign things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not issue out from the limbs on which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through a drawing back of themselves from the place from which they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or contrariwise in another part of it.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which issues out from where it entered, is either an arrow proceeding to a fleshy place and being drawn back, and issuing forth.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	But if it does not comply with going out from the hour in which it fell: then it is necessary to let it be for some days, until the flesh around it putsrefies: and its attraction is alleviated, and its egress facilitated.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is stuck in a bone and does not comply with you for exiting, then let it be also for some days: and work on it every day with attrition and motion, until it issues forth.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	But if it does not comply with you for exiting after days, then it is necessary to pierce around the arrow on the bone from every part with a fine awl, until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head and has already proceeded into one of the brain's ventricles, and some of those things that I said appear from the patient: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and let it be, until its condition becomes suitable after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if an arrow has reached the spleen, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except in the body of a bone only, and does not penetrate as far as the spleen: and the patient remains sick for several days, and nothing bad happens to him from these accidents: then skill is required in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is very fixed and does not obey you to the drawing: then administer tar on the circumference of the arrow, as I have told you previously: then care for the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is now hidden in the body's location and is concealed and hidden from sense: then seek it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you are not able to reach over it because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow in depth, and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein: then dig into it until the wound is enlarged and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
