Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	But if there are ears by which it is held fast, then free the fixed flesh on them from all parts, with every skill that you can use it, and be skilled, if you cannot overcome the evasion of the flesh in the fracture of the ears, and their twisting, until it escapes.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever location it is, then use twisting with your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you make it escape: and subtlely, with the ultimate subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and becomes difficult for you to draw out and extract.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	But if you are not able over it on the same day, then leave it for several days until what is around it has become putrid.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then go at it again: for the membrane will have relaxed. But if it causes you a flow of blood, then administer what we said in its cure in its own chapter: and guard your strength from an incision of a vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the treatment of an arrow wound in every way possible for you to do so with ease and tranquility, or slowness and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do this when drawing the arrow, so that the patient will be weak according to form, according to which he was at the time of the case of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible from the forms.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow that has gone out from the opposite part of another or is already proceeding from it something to the exterior: or makes a swelling of the tip of the arrow by feeling from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it prominent: therefore cut over it, and let the cutting be according to the size of what the forceps take up in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for indeed it becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If however it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to roundness, until the arrow prints itself in the bone and makes itself larger: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not, leave it for a few days: then try to draw it out, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	For if the wood of the arrow is in her, then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the wood has fallen and you wish to administer a push, then insert into her a concave instrument, so that its concavity may enter the tail of the arrow: then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the arrow is concave, then push it out with an instrument that enters into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is eased by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	But if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary that you hollow out all the flesh in which the poison is: if that is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then cure it as befits that one.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling into the chest, or belly, or bladder, or side, and is near to what you touch with the probe, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut, and beware of cutting into a vein, or nerve, and draw it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then if you see the wound, and cure it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of forceps with which arrows are drawn out.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let their extremities be like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they take hold of an arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are made in many forms, great, small, and medium, according to the size of the arrow, and its thinness, and the width of the wound, and the constriction of it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of a scoop is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the shape of a scoop is blunt.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is a blunt end like a radius, so that its entrance into the concave arrow may be eased and it may be pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of the concave scoop is itself concave like a bird's feather, so that the entrance of the arrow into it may be eased and its thrust.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Concerning venesection.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins to be cut for venesection, whose habit is accustomed in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of which there are sixteen in the head: two pulsatile veins, which are behind the ears, called the two Herbs: and two arteries, which are appearing in both temporal bones: and two veins which are in the corners of both tear ducts of the eyes, which are called Seers: and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two glands which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are on the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And those are veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	However, those veins that are cut on the arms, are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and it is from the outer side of the shoulder; and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Median (or) the Furcation.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Median vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilica and a branch of the Cephalica; and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, and it is placed on the inner side of the arm; and it is also called the Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the tendon of the arm, and it is placed above the elbow; and it is that one where bloodletting is done, and it is that one which appears above the wrist with a clear appearance.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is a vein which is between the annular and the smallest [ones]: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And on the leg and foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curve of the big toe from the outer side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second one is the Saphena: and its location is near the heel from the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Nesse: and its location is near the heel from the outer side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And on the other leg there are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	About bloodletting from two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	But the bloodletting of two veins which are behind the ears is a remedy for old coughs, and hemicrania, and scrofula, and evil old sores on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting in her is according to what I say.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is done, so that the head of the ailing person is scraped and her occiput is rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth in good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the ailing person should tighten his neck with a thread until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the places of them are behind the ears in two places on a depressed head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore search for them with your finger and where you feel their pulse under your finger, mark that place with wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the lancet of bloodletting, and it is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein on the skin until the bloodletting reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift up your hand with the vein and the skin to the upper part, and make an incision on the vein with a cutting incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be as much as two joined fingers or about that: and make come out from blood as much as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with lint, and leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now precedent to the beginning of the book was their cutting, and their cauterying.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Concerning bloodletting of two Arteries in time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The bloodletting of the two arteries which are in the two temporal veins is useful for an old headache, and bad fever, and constant watering of the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting them is according to what I say to you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The ailing person should tighten his neck much until two veins appear to the sense in a clear appearance: and their pulse should be shown under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark with wax.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift up the skin from above the vein with your index finger, and insert the lancet underneath, and lift up the vein to the upper part.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut into it, as you did with the two other veins: and let blood flow from it according to the quantity of your necessity.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then relieve the constriction of the patient, and place your finger upon the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put a linen cloth or a poultice on it and bind with a strong bandage above the constriction: and leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now this is a reminder of them, and their incision, and extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	About phlebotomy of the vein of the forehead after cephalic phlebotomy.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The application for the phlebotomy of the vein of the forehead is after cephalic phlebotomy, for old affections of the face: and for hemicrania, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is, as I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient constricts his neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called a Trephine.
Cuius haec est forma.	Which has this form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the projecting point that is at the head of the Trephine over the vein, and strike upon it with a spatula or another thing in its manner: and let blood flow according to what you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then relieve the patient's perforation and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it opens with a wide phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it should not be a sharp extremity of the incision, like the other bleedings, but rather a wide extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And let the bleeding be according to the fracture, because the bone is nearby: and perhaps the bleeding will break when it is thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	About the phlebotomy of the veins in both eyelids.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of the two veins which are in the two eyelids of both eyes, is for an eye with itch and redness: and swelling in the eye, and afflictions of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the venesection of them is, that it constricts a weak neck with a thread.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then make an incision on them and you be standing above his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And the venesection should be made across according to its length a little, with a small, wide lancet, because there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the venesection is thin at the extremity, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make blood flow out of them as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put on top of them a bandage and tie them one night, and release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the venesection of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose that are subject to venesection, is bringing aid against acute fever and intense headache, and afflictions of the face, such as hemicrania, and redness which occurs on the face; especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the venesection of them is, that it constricts a weak neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the nose of him with your left hand, and take a fine, long lancet for venesection, and fix it in the middle of his nostril, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because a vein does not appear to sight there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you stretch out your hand a little with the lancet, and make blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind up the same one for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the venesection of the veins of the neck (or goitre).
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Of the two Guidicgi bleedings, the remedy is for constriction of panting, and seizure of leprosy, and melancholic sufferings, and impetigo, and bad ulcers, and eating sores, that is, corrosive herpes.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of these bleedings is that the patient should be seated under both under his own neck with a bandage; and the artist should stand over the head of the sick person, and the sick person should be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the vein wide in breadth for the bleeding about as long as the width of the bleeding needle.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood a quantity tempered or according to what you see as necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then untie the bandage and bind the two veins with a moderate constriction, so that the sick person does not faint.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her be until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On the bleeding of veins by Algeberic.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberic's bleeding remedy is, because it brings for the swelling in the mouth, and corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers: and fissures of the lips: and bad ulcers, also which are in the nose, and around its surroundings.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of these bleedings is that you make the sick person sit before you: and bind his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll back his lip and look at the two veins, one from the right side of his lip, and the second from the left side of him, and the demonstration of each is by the blackness on both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And it is true that around them are small veins, dark-colored.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut therefore both with a cut of cutting.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt over you, and you do not know which one of them it is: then look at the cut of the larger of them, and that will be clearer.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do this with two veins which are on the upper lip, and indeed customarily they run together with it; and cut two veins that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Concerning bloodletting from veins under the tongue after cephalic bloodletting.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The benefit of bloodletting from the two veins under the tongue is that cephalic bloodletting is for afflictions which are in the throat, and suffering of the uvula, and sufferings of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bloodletting from them is that the sick person should sit between your hands in front of the sun; and elevate his tongue and look under his tongue from one side a vein, and from the other side another vein: and the colour of each declivity to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore bleed both of them and take care that you do not finish your hand with bleeding them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under those are arteries, and perhaps a flow of blood will occur from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Concerning the three veins in the forearm.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins which are bled on the forearm are those of whose bloodletting custom has run in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their bloodletting is done by two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either puncturing with a myrtle-pointed lancet or oiling to the subtlety of the declivity, or cutting with a surgical knife, and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which is suited to cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are kinds wide and subtle according to the amplitude of the veins and their constriction. The form of the lancet is broad, as you see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it suits to open veins which are concave, full, proceeding, apparent, thick, and those which contain thick, cloudy blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of smaller width and more delicate edges.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it suits the lancing of thin veins which contain a thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	About the lancet for the basilic vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, the basilic vein, which is one of these three useful veins, is suitable.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from ailments that are under the throat and neck, because they follow the chest and belly: and it suits the lancer to lance it with caution, and be afraid of it since there is an artery under it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	Therefore, if he makes a mistake and adds blood to the puncture of the lancet, he will strike that artery, and a flow of blood will occur.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary, so that the lancer does not lance it with the piercing lancet: rather let him incise it with an Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	But if the basilic vein does not appear in a manifest appearance, then it is necessary to go elsewhere and to seek another branch of it, or to lance the arm's tendon.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it itself is manifest, and cut it with an Alnesil lancet, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you wish to lance the vein itself of this one, then it is necessary before tying up the arm, that you touch the place until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with wax, afterwards the arm, and cut the vein with a concave incision with an Alnesil lancet, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware lest the blow fall through space to the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, with you tying the bandage, swelling in the place which you marked with wax, then that swelling is an inflation of the artery: therefore abandon it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	Which if you see blood welling up in the lancet wound, like a child's urine, and it is thin, red blood: then you know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore hasten, and place your finger over it on a long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	Since then blood is cut off (for it is indeed often cut off) then tie the arm and leave it: and let the patient beware of its movement: and be on his guard against fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if blood is not cut off and you are overcome, and medicine is not present to you at the moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities contract and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of a papyrus stem, and scrape it clean: take half one and tie it over the place of the vein constriction fittingly, with a ligature and poultice until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not, then treat it with the one whose reminder preceded the removal of the flow of blood from the place of powder: and cutting off his blood is not difficult in many dispositions because of the small location of the wound and the possibility of tying the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	About venesection of the black vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The black vein's venesection is useful, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower body: therefore, because it is composed of a branch of the basilic and a branch of the cephalic, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it suits the venesector to take it above fear from its venesection, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	So if he adds to the venesection wound and finds a nerve, it happens that there is a dullness, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it does not heal at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If it is hidden in some people and is subtle, and does not show itself: then you should put your phlebotomy tool where you would bleed her with a cut made with Alnasir's blade, and pull out the vein with all your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The help or aid of the cephalic vein phlebotomy is that it draws blood from the head and relieves eye afflictions.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein, properly speaking, if you want, to bleed her puncturing with a phlebotomy olive or myrtle: because it is the safest of all veins, since there is no artery below it nor nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However it is fitting for you with the phlebotomy that you pull out with a phlebotomy hook just as much of the head as possible, and seek out a softer place: and it does not harm him if it is not found with the first stroke, so that it may be repeated over her with the phlebotomy several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However perhaps it may suppurate in some people when not bled in the first stroke, but that suppurating does not harm him at all.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the utility of phlebotomy and on cautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	But the quality however of phlebotomy, and accidents from it, in whose correction you ought to think.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Therefore first of all it is necessary for you to know that phlebotomy is not administered unless in the preservation and perseverance of health, and caution against the onset of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so that phlebotomy may be done on one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the cephalic, and the basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that phlebotomy may be done at the beginning of spring after a fast, and in summer, and autumn, and winter after digestion, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let bloodletting be done on the first day, or on the third, after three hours have passed since sunrise.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, bloodletting which is administered for illnesses does not have a fixed hour; but when it prompts convenience and necessity to do so, at night or by day, and in any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not fitting that children should be let blooded until they come on fourteen years.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be let blooded, unless from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And also old men who have already passed sixty years should not be let blooded.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	So when someone wants to let blood for whatever reason: it is necessary that they purify their intestines beforehand with a gentle enema, if much feces has been retained in them: so that the veins are not attracted by the superfluous and putrid things from the intestines which are harmful to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	And neither should the patient be let blood who is suffering from nausea and vomiting, nor one who has drunk too much, nor one fleeing from drunkenness, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor one who is weak with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let bloodletting be avoided again after a colic episode, and vomiting, and diarrhea, and the increase of coitus, and labor, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and all that dissolves the strength from bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider beforehand the subtlety of humors before doing it, whether the blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medicines; if it is possible to him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him enter a bath, if nothing prevents him from doing so; or he should exercise in some manner, so that the blood may be thinned.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the bloodletting of him on the chest, around the third part of the day, as we have said; and try to empty his chest that day from all bad animal affections: such as anxiety, and anger, and fear: and also from all bodily affections: such as labor, and pain, and superfluity, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him sit his patients so that they are present with things of which the custom of men has run in use by way of aromatics, and scenting, and festivity, and similar ones to these as far as possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the bloodletting person sit on a cushion higher than that of the one being bloodleted. Afterwards, he should withdraw his arm and rub it with his hand twice, or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him bind the cord with a strap, and wrap them around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be tempered, because a constriction when uneven, or through excess in the constriction then prevents the flow of blood; or in relaxation, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction it is necessary that the one being bloodleted rub his hands together closely until the veins become swollen and are felt.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the bloodletting person should wipe the bloodletting site with a little old oil.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place the index finger of his left hand on top of the vein in the location where he wants to make the bloodletting, a little bit so that the vein does not escape and the blow is struck.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because from the veins is what is found like a fleeing string at bloodletting: and from them is that which is full of venosity: and when you place the bloodletting instrument on it, it constricts under the bloodletting instrument, and deceives the bloodletter, and the bloodletting instrument does not open the vein: and if it opens it, it is tightened: therefore it is necessary that the bloodletter be firm and solicitous in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then let him remove the bloodletting instrument.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein is opened on the right side first, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat that on the other side a little below or above it with haste: if the place does not become inflamed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If an abscess forms, or the patient becomes inflamed, then let him rest for a day, or two days; and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed the abscess will draw to itself heat.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let him not enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he should repeat bloodletting, if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	And if the opening is small, or the blood flows finely, and you fear that not enough will come out from the blood, then repeat the bloodletting in the same place itself according to rightness, and add a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it with haste, before the abscess forms, for the place of the abscess is often in many people at a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	So if then you see that it is already an abscess, then do not repeat the procedure over it at all, for nothing excuses itself with you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something from olive dung over it, for it will ease the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than the oil itself and than the other olive substances.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer olive dung in every bloodletting of yours, by which you let out veins at the prohibition of the course of blood; and they make it theriac of Alfarache, and sage wine, when something is put from one of them over the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood is refined and resolved, when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	And if an abscess happens at the place of bloodletting, for it often does happen, especially to those who are not bloodletted except that time, or have small opening veins, then hurry and put over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed slightly: and bind it for one hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do that after the blood comes out from the vein itself, with its completion, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something remains in place after some days with blackness or greenness, it does not harm; and if you wish, put something of aloe or myrrh solution over it, or something from the juice of mint, that is, bergamot or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed many times abscesses and swellings occur in bloodletting at the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So put your hand over it then, if you find softness under your pressure on it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Be careful therefore to put something over it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood may flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for him with that in which is bitterness, so that the place may harden.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the remaining cure, until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you take out all blood from a man according to his strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears by the color winning over blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it go out until it becomes red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it go out until it thins; and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs a blood extraction once, that the venesection be increased, and be a lateral venesection; and contrariwise for one who is weak.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he take it out in sections, and that the opening be tight; and better when bloodletting a vein is, that there be a cross-cut incision, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this manner of bloodletting is safe from a flow of blood and an incision of the nerve; and it is more praiseworthy and safer than bloodletting by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is accustomed to go for bloodletting from the cupping vessel, it is necessary that he eat beforehand a little bread infused with grape juice water: or crushed pomegranate seeds if it is warm: and take out from his blood in three times, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is chilled complexion, then let him take beforehand bread infused with honey syrup, or with honeyed syrup scented with spices, or with a fragrant sweet syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	But if a cupping vessel occurs at the phlebotomy site and it is the cause of his exit of blood much, then it is necessary that he drink in drink water of flesh, and a subtle fragrant syrup: and use aromatics with galangal, and anoint his chest with them: and use the rest which we said in the division in the chapter on cupping from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But he who wants to succeed in his arm and release his blood second: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is because of great evacuation, and the strength of his body is weak, that he release the blood little by little according to the quantity of virtue in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But he who wants to succeed in his arm and release his blood second, and is the body of him strong: then let him do it after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	But he who wants to attract blood from his body to the contrary part to which it declines: it is necessary that he succeed in him on the second day, or the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body is much blood already warmed up, and sharpened, and makes fever occur: it is necessary that the blood go out of him in one place, and a great quantity be taken from him: and the opening be widened until cupping occurs: after you have been preserving all conditions of phlebotomy, and as you put your hand on his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death does not occur at the site of cupping.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For often it happens that a phlebotomist is unaware of this, and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not fitting when you wish to cut an arm and let out blood in the second place, with the vessel already closed and the exit of the blood made difficult, that you press upon it with vehemence and stretch it quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For this is very evil, nay let it be left until bloodletting takes place in the second place.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove that which has coagulated from the blood in the vessel with a sharpness of bloodletting, and place over it something dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place over it something of theriac algarroch or sugarcane, and bind it gently with a bandage until the blood goes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If however the vein is already inflamed, then leave it and do not bandage it until the inflammation subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity calls for letting out blood a second time and there is no excuse, then either let it be done above that place or on the other arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The cord of the arm is however bloodletted at the place of the Basilica and the Saphena, when they cannot be found, because they are hidden and composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of bloodletting is that a sick person should put his hand into hot water until it reddens and the vein becomes clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then let a ligament be stretched over it with a moderate degree of constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then bloodletting should be done across, gradually, not in breadth or length; and let the opening be wide, and your bloodletting should be such that you bleed on top of the joint of the hand for a little while.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	And if the exit of blood is prevented, then repeat with your hand into hot water, and let the blood flow into the water until you accomplish your necessity.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are however in the days of summer, then excuse yourself from washing hands with hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed a flow of blood is put in hot water especially during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the venesection of this vein is safer than all veins, because there is not under it a pulsatile vein, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The venesection of the right hand's Saluatella vein indeed aggravates affections of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this venesection is, that you tie a string on the hand with ligament, or your own hand, after you have put it into hot water until the vein inflates and becomes apparent to sense greatly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then perform venesection by crossing over it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut into her entirely, it will not harm her in anything.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And take care, lest you exhaust your hand with venesection.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the naked nerves of the fingers bare of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then wash your hand again with hot water and let blood flow in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not wash it again in hot water, the blood will clot in the vein's opening and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	Therefore when you have taken out a quantity of blood as is necessary, then place oil and salt over the vein so that it does not become constricted quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly you should do with every tightened branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The dressing for the venesection of this vein from the left hand is: because it is conducive to affections of the spleen: and similarly do in its venesection, as you did in the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The dressing for the venesection of the saphena vein is for afflictions that are in the lower part of the body, such as pains of the womb and retention of menses, and weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and legs, and similar afflictions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is this: that the infirm person puts his foot into warm water: and makes a friction on it, until the veins swell: and he binds above the joint of the foot with a cord.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed the location of the veins is near the heel, appearing towards the thumb; and they branch off from it into the face of the foot, many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore he performs phlebotomy on it in its larger branch, or near the heel in its cluster, because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	But if he performs phlebotomy on it in the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves which are under it above the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy so that you cut into it from a crosswise direction, as if you want to sever it; and let the incision be crosswise.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if exit of blood is forbidden, then send his foot into warm water; and let the blood run into it until it is drained.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	But if the phlebotomist mistakes the vein at first time, then repeat it with the incision a little higher up, for the place is safe, and you do not fear harm from it, when you beware of nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the vein of the other foot which is equal in size.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the location of the sciatic veins, as we said, is near the heel on the outside part.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the benefit of his phlebotomy is for the pain of the ankle when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that the infirm person enters the bath and hurries; and he tightens his leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel by four fingers with a thin string, long; for it does not appear unless on account of this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then perform phlebotomy on it in whatever manner is possible for you, or crosswise; and it is better, or as if you want to cut into it with an incision, or to sever it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place of it is safer, and itself is very much hidden in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	But if you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the senses: then make an incision in one of its branches, which is that which appears on the back of the foot and towards the ear; and be careful around the nerves, and let blood flow out as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and place skin over the site of the blood-letting, and bind the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is healed quickly indeed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of wind, and its quality of use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Wind-colics are made from horns, and from the air, and from vinegar.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And wind-colic indeed is caused in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When with scarification and bloodletting: and the other is wind-colic without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this wind-colic which is without scarification, is according to two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or indeed it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And wind-colic remedies which are administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is the back of the head; and Alkehel, and it is the middle of the neck; and wind-colic Alhagdahim, and they are two plates of the neck at the same time from both sides; and wind-colic of the mind, and it is under the jaw in the lower mouth; and wind-colic of the spatula, and it is on the edges of the nostrils; and wind-colic Alachosos on the end of the tail; and wind-colic of the two forelimbs, and they are the middle of the two arms; and wind-colic of the two hind legs; and wind-colic of the two caudal horns.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And wind-colic indeed does not let blood out of you from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of that its virtue does not fall out of them, as is the case with venesection.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	And it is not necessary to administer venesection with fire, or without fire, in any affliction that arises frompletion, until the whole body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity calls for venesection because of an affliction or due to habit, let us administer it at the beginning and end of the month, and in the middle thereof, and at whatever time it may be necessary.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Which is because from people it comes that when the blood multiplies in him until he needs its extraction by venesection, finds a heaviness and congestion in his head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them is who finds repletion and redness in his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them is who finds itching on his face and forehead, and darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them is who feels pain or scabbing at the site of venesection.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them is who has his laughter multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them is who finds the taste of blood in his mouth; or his tongue is ulcerated and spits up blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them is who has his sleep multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them is who sees blood and redness, and the slain and wounds, and things similar to those, in his sleep.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something from among those things, and if it is properly in the third part of the month: then let us command venesection to be done, after two or three hours have passed by during the day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The juice of venesection is however a nuisance because it causes heaviness in the head and what is poured out affects the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But indeed it should be after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is venesection in place of phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted for someone who has a cold complexion, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it will cause him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And on account of this they should not use those things for the aged, and for whom there are cold ailments on their head.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But whoever is accustomed to it will forget about it.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And on account of this it is necessary to command the patient to put his hand with the poultice a little below for a short time, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Alkehel is a place in the stead of dark bloodletting and black bloodletting, and on account of this it brings relief from shortness of breath, constriction of breathing, rupture of instruments of breathing, coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary to be stirred up the Ventosation of Alkehel a little, because if it is put below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosation indeed alhagdahim brings relief to pains happening accidentally in the head and to eyes, and to hemicrania, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is a place in the stead of black bloodletting.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to command the patient that he should not press his hand with scarification so that an artery may not be cut and a flow of blood occur.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosation indeed under the chin brings relief to ulcers in the mouth and corruption of the gum and similar things from ailments that are in the mouth: and it is a place for bloodletting which is in both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosation indeed of spatulae brings relief to alchafacham, which occurs from inflammation and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventosation indeed of the inner parts of the two hollows brings relief to the help of bloodletting from the three veins, Basilicae, Fuscae, and Cephalicae: because it attracts blood from all those tiny veins that are in the flesh: and those tiny veins attract blood from other larger veins until attraction comes to the three.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary, as you direct the Ventosatori, that he not proceed too much in scarification: for the place is stripped of skin, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But the ventosa that is applied over ulcers causes hemorrhoids in the anus, and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary, as you direct the Ventosatori, that the ventosa be large and made of air: for the place needs a strong suction, and perhaps the delicate vents break: and let there be a large scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The ventoses of the legs decrease them by a manifest diminution: for they draw blood from the whole body, and bring on old pains in the kidneys, womb, and bladder: they provoke menstruation, and bring on dropsy, and edema; and they stand in place of venesection of both saphenous veins, and of altorcofeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However they weaken the body much, and cause syncope to occur in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the help of altorcofeni ventoses is close to the help of two leg ventoses.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of ventoses is that you place the ventosa first in a vacant place and suck with tempered suction; and do not prolong the position of the ventoses, but put them quickly and remove them quickly, so that the humors come to the place at an equal arrival: and do not cease to repeat it and continue, until you see the place already red and inflamed, and the appearance of blood-redness appears: then therefore scarify and repeat suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in arrangement of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For those from men who have tender flesh, rare pores, it is necessary that you scarify him once, no more: so that the place does not become ulcerous.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And direct the Ventosatori to amplify the scarification and to make it a little deep; and to temper the suction with ease, swiftness, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a clot in the blood, then it should be cut with a knife twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Indeed on the first occasion an opening is made for the subtlety of blood and its moistness; and on the second occasion a searching extraction of the thickened blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is very foul, then let there be a cut on the third occasion: so that it may finally come out.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And for the last thing, when we wish to withdraw the blood little by little, or a bit at a time, one cut is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	For if we wish to make many extractions of the blood, let us make multiple cuts.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure, that the blood is thick: then it is necessary, to let it be cut with a deep cut; and the end of the cut, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What that should be administered from oils at the placement of Ventosae, and what the Ventosane should beware.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that person indeed whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and whose pores are tight, it should be necessary for them to anoint the places of Ventosare with oils opened, softened, dissolved; if it is in the time of summer, as is oil of Alcheirum, or violatum oil, or oil of sweet almonds, or oil of cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then oil of narcissus, or oil of lily, or oil of chamomel, or of sarsaparilla: and things similar to these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If indeed the superfluity is thick, cold: then let the oil be bitter almond, or oil of myrrh, or white oil, or oil of aloe: and things similar to these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If indeed the patient is of many pores, tender flesh: then it should be necessary to prohibit them from oil, and it should be necessary for them to wash the places of Ventosare after ventosation with rose water, or cold water, or with water of sage, or with cucumber water, or with water of portulaca: and things similar to these.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of great humidity, should wash the veins with vinegar or water of myrtle and sumac, and similar things.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	For whose swellings are coarse, he should wash the veins with old wine, or with water of samseed, or with a decoction of dill, or chamomile, and similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that a vein is not let out at the bath, or at the sign of the bath, nay, it is necessary that it be administered after going out from the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for someone to sleep after venesection.
