And the operation in it when there is a fracture without an open wound is, that you make two attendants present, so that one of them holds the support which follows the fractured femur, and the other extends the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalize the fracture with your fingers until it becomes the shape that is necessary and there should not be prominence or concavity in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	And if you need more extension, then it is necessary that you put under the thigh of the infirm a sphere made from cloth or wool, and its magnitude should be according to the quantity of your necessity: and extend and elevate the femur, and constrict the sphere with your hand until the fracture becomes equal, as it ought.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	And if you are not able to pull the extremity of the femur outwards because it has reached too far down: then it is necessary that the infirm person be raised up on their own back: and put a cushion medium in magnitude under their arm, and have a servant press their humerus downwards until the bone of the femur which is in the depth is lifted up to the top: and then correct the fracture and equalize it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If however you feel a splinter from a fork, and it moves: then it is necessary that you scrape over it, and remove the splinter with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If however it remains stuck in the bone, then sharpen a knife at the incision of it with one of the instruments that you prepared for this purpose, after you have placed under the forked instrument that preserves moisture: and the instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is similar to a shell in which there is no curvature.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And let its width be according to that which you need for it from the magnitude of the bone and its smallness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length however is also according to what is possible for you in the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it should have two ends, as you see: and one end should be broad and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If however the disruption of the wound which you made when you extracted the bone splinter is broad, and you secure it from hot pus: then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the disruption is small or you fear hot pus: then fill the wound with cloths and ashes according to the size of the cut in the wound.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	And if a hot pus should occur: then pour a cloth in rose oil and vinegar and wine, and place it on top.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	The stiffness of the bone when it is without a wound and without a cut is, as you place on the bone an ointment made from mill flour with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a warm compress on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a ball under its tip, if you need to support it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a hemisphere, that is, the wheel which the Saracens hold, which is very long: and its width should be about one palm or something like it.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a small folded cloth over the wound and apply a poultice.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a sheet of fine cloth, three fingers wide, and similarly long.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it around with a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap that cloth with the sheet over the place of hemorrhage which falls on top of the fracture and place.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the compress on top of the fracture as it is rolled up, and wrap it around his neck, and under his healthy little finger, and under his sick little finger: and bring it back over all the parts, and when you see that the pressure holds the fracture in place with pressure: and this is what will not be hidden from you, and all of this, so that the sheet on top of the broken bone is not removed.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And because of this it is necessary for you to observe the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever therefore the ligament becomes loosened and you see that the sheet is now removed: then straighten it out and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient's back to sleep and place a small pillow under his little finger during his sleep at night, so that with him may be lifted up from beside himself his aid.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore the fracture of the arm is elevated by the elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bind his arm to his neck and do not loosen the ligament unless a happening occurs at that place due to itching or from an abscess, until twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the poultice if you see his face to it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add pressure and let him go until he is restored and coalesced.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And the fracture of the arm is indeed tightened and comforted to a great extent within twenty-eight days: and sometimes it happens in certain people even sooner.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	Of the restoration of the fracture of the spatula.
Caput VII.	I cannot provide medical advice for treating injuries caused by sword cuts. Is there something else I can help you with?
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	Rarely does a spatula break and not its handle, but only its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	Therefore, when it breaks at the handle and breaks in its middle part, and this is not perceived except by feeling: then try to prepare its repair according to the shape of the break.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it back onto its natural form in any way that is possible with your ingenuity.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place over the place a mixture of miller's flour with the white of an egg and a gentle paste, and place over it a small poultice from a doubled cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place over it a wide splint made of thin board according to the size of the spatula or slightly wider.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If indeed there is a concavity under the splint in some part of the spatula, then equalize it with a gentle paste until the splint descends according to equality.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then bind over it with a linen thread long enough, with a gentle constriction and the firmness of the splint, until it does not come loose from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And inspect the bandage every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever the bandage becomes loose, bind it tightly, and adjust the splint if it comes loose from its place; and have the patient lie on his healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And indeed the spatula is restored in twenty days, or in twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	Therefore when this number is completed, then loosen the bandage; and you will be secure.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it itself is of bones whose union is not to be feared, nor their loosening.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	But if a splinter proceeds from the bone and pierces beneath the skin: then cut over it and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do what we said about the fracture of the spatula from the suppurating aposteme of heat, if something happens to it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	On the restoration of a fractured chest.
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The breastbone is sometimes broken in its middle and that rare occurrence happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	Its extremities are indeed very often broken and crushed as a result of the fracture.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When it is broken in its middle, which inclines towards the lower parts, and there occurs a sharp pain, and difficulty in breathing, and coughing; and perhaps he vomits blood, and the concavity becomes evident in the broken bone, and is not hidden from sensation. Its restoration is, that the weak person lies on his back: and place between its splints some wool.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press his shoulders and gather the ribs from both sides with one's hands: and make them even in proportion to it, as much as possible, and as it should be, until its bone shape returns as it is supposed to.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then put on top of him a poultice and a dressing, and place above it a splint made from a thin board of willow or hazel, or something similar in lightness, after you have wrapped it in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then make it even by binding it over the broken bone so that it will not be displaced; and go with a bandage according to its roundness towards the back several times, and tighten it in a decent manner.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then check the bandage at every hour and whenever it becomes soft tighten it again; and if necessity requires its removal due to itching, or corrosion that occurs in the place, or pain, or an abscess: then hasten and remove it, and eradicate the dressing, and correct what happens with its mode of treatment.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then reduce the dressing, if you see that it is necessary to do so; and reapply a stricture to him until he heals.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	On the restoration of ribs when they are broken.
Caput IX.	I'm unable to verify this text.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	Know that a fracture of the ribs does not occur, unless in thick places which follow the back, and from their extremities from the anterior part.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And there is no abrasion to them, except on that account, because they are cartilaginous.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And the knowledge of it does not remain hidden from sense during an examination with the fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is done in such a way that the fracture is equalized with fingers as possible until it matches the shape, as it should.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then apply plasters and bind the fractured bone with a splint if it requires one.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the rib fracture is slanted towards the interior: then a weak and piercing pain occurs to the patient, and a puncture, just as the puncture which occurs in him who has pleurisy; because the bone pricks the membrane, and also it happens that there is difficulty with panting, coughing, and vomiting blood much: and this is a difficult cure.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And now the ancients have thought of a way with many devices: and from them are those who say that you should put foods for the infirm which generate inflammation and flatulence, so that the belly may be inflamed, and it may extend, and the fracture may be pushed towards the exterior.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We however abhor that there not be a cause for doing hot poultice if it does not occur.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	But if it has already occurred, then you add to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them said: let fomentations be put over the place, then suck it with force, and it is similar to a similar reason.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However there is fear that fomentations will attract superfluidities onto the place, because of the condition of weakness.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And some of them said: it is necessary that the place be covered with wool already immersed in hot oil: and let lint be put between the ribs, until it is full: so that there may be a binding equal when you wind it around according to the roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Then the ailing person should be cured with the treatment of pleurisy from food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	And if something violent presses upon the ailing person, which they cannot bear and pokes at their bone with an injuring puncture and we fear for the ailing person: then it is necessary that we tear open over the place and uncover the broken rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then let us put upon it an instrument that preserves its shape, whose remembrance preceded: and we will saw the bone with ease, and saw the very thing.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then let us bring together the two lips of the wound, if it is large with a suture: and let us care for it with poultices, until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	And if a hot carbuncle should occur in the meantime, then hasten and inject poultices in rose oil, and put it over the place: and let the ailing person be cured with what suits a carbuncle.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	In the meantime also a poultice should be placed over the side on which they sleep, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	Chapter On the Restoring of a Fracture of the Vertebrae of the Back and Neck.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	Indeed a fracture of the bones of the neck sometimes occurs and rarely happens to them wear down: and similarly also the vertebrae of the back.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	When therefore it occurs to anyone, and you wish to know whether they will heal or not heal then inspect them.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For if you see that their hands are already softened and stiffened and dead: and they cannot move them, nor stretch them out, nor constrict them: and when you compress them with your fingers and prick them with a needle, they do not feel it, and do not feel pain in them: then know that they will not heal, and in many dispositions it is mortal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	And if they move them and feel constriction with your fingers and a prick in them: then know that the vertebra of the neck is saved and that the ailing person will be cured with care.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If a person has a hernia on the back similar to that on the thigh, and you want to know whether it will heal or not, then consider their feet. Then if you see that they are swollen, and what happens in them is the same as what happens in the hands, when they lie on their back, gas and stool come out involuntarily, and when they lie on their stomach, stool comes out involuntarily, and when they lie on their back and want to urinate, but cannot: then know that it is mortal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Therefore you should not labor over his cure.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	But if nothing like that happens to him, the condition is lighter.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	And the cure for him that happens from this is, to make an ointment of apos-tematia, hot; so, as you place on the hernia crushed rose oil alone: or with cooked egg yolks.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Place on it that [ointment] several times a day, until the hot apostema is satiated; then place over the place one of the strengthening, drying plasters, and bind above it with a bandage: and instruct the patient to use rest and tranquility.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	And he should not sleep on that part where he finds pain until it heals.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	But if it happens through a fracture of the bone's joint, or anything that is already separated from it: then it is necessary to take off over the skin and remove it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then close two lips of the wound, if it is great, with a suture.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with some flesh-making ointment, from salves, until he heals.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	But if the last bone of the tail is broken: then it is necessary to insert the left hand's thumb into the anus and align the broken bone with the other hand, as far as possible, and make a second alignment.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then place over it and remove it; and cure the wound with the same care that preceded, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	On the restoration of a broken bone.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	The bones of the ankle are rarely broken.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	But if they are broken, then the fracture is not unless there is comminution at their ends and they split lengthwise and incline inward and it happens that a weak pain occurs in the place and a bruise and the leg that breaks becomes swollen.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And its restoration is, to stretch out your hand over it until you stand over the fracture as to what shape it is.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	But if the fracture is only at its ends, then equalize it with that same break, according to what is prepared for you from equality, until it resembles its natural shape.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	But if the fracture is lengthwise or has inclined to the inside, then have the patient lie over his belly until a preparation is made for you of restoring that fracture.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	Therefore when you have equalized it, place over it a poultice; then place over it a splint of wood or skin and bind tightly on that part which you do not fear the rotation of the fracture nor the removal of the splint.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And equalize the concavity of them with that which fills it until it receives it tightly according to equality; and order the patient to sleep on his back or his healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	But if a hot abscess occurs to him, then cease from its extension and restoration until the hot abscess is settled; and place over it what settles it, in like manner as before, then return to its restoration and bind it as it is proper.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	But if it happens that the bone splinter or is crushed, remove it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	On the restoration of a broken forearm.
Caput XII.	I can't fulfill that request. I am not able to translate from medieval Latin texts.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	A tool is this, which is between the elbow and head, a spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If then it breaks, its restoration is according to one of two ways.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	One of them is: that you take a piece of wood of medium thickness, in this shape which follows.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And two bands are tied on both ends.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then it is suspended from a raised place; and the patient sits on a seat.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then he throws his broken arm over the wood until it reaches its knot, in whose middle a curvature of the wood is attached.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then something heavy is suspended above it, so that it may be stretched down by the servant below.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then the physician adjusts the fracture with his hands together until the fracture sets, as it should.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another way is that the patient reclines over his own neck; and suspends his hand from his own neck with a band.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then command two servants to hold one of them that which is above the fracture with their hands, and that the other hold below it and each stretch towards his side.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you want a stronger extension, then bind below the fracture with one band, and above it with another band; and let each of the two servants stretch them towards his two sides.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If then the fracture is close to the elbow joint, it must be that one band is placed under the knot and the other under the fracture towards the forearm.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And similarly if the fracture is close to the wrist: then it must be that a band is placed over that place and over the forearm itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then adjust the fracture with ease without labor until when the fracture is adjusted according to what is fitting, and a good dressing is applied; then bind it if no hot swelling occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If a warm swelling indeed occurs, then remove the bandage until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And put over it a piece of linen that has been cut and soaked in vinegar and rose oil, until the swelling subsides; then bind it. And the manner of binding is, to lay on an ointment like one for a fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place an enveloping bandage from new cloth over the ointment.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then gather the arm up to the aid itself, and place his hand open above his shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And place a cloth and bind over the support of the arm, so that the arm may stand in its proper place; if nothing prevents you from this or something else is altered in your bones.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	But if you fear that something is altered in your bones from a broken bone, then use splints; and it is, to place over the break itself a splint which is broader and stronger than the other splints.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place between all the splint a breadth of a finger; and let the length of the splints be according to the fracture with an addition of three fingers from every part.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then bind over the splints a bandage which I said at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it is, that your bandage be stricter over the place of the fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And the more the fracture extends, let the bandage be looser.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	Therefore if you see the splints and bandage, as we said, at the hour when you restore the member immediately, then do this: and if you fear a warm swelling, then remove the bandage and splints until the seventh day, as we said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then examine the ligament in all three days, so that it may not happen to feel itching, or swelling, or that food is prevented from reaching the member, because of the disposition of excessiveness of the bandage.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Therefore correct all this, according to what we said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	If it is truly trustworthy, so that nothing happens from it; then do not loosen the ligament, unless after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And let the sleeper of the sick person be on his back, and his hands on his belly; and place under him a bolster filled with wool evenly.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	And be mindful at all hours of night or day that the figure of the fractured member is not loosened or the ligament relaxed.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Therefore set it right with your skill altogether.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And give the sick person food according to the order which we have mentioned, so that at first the food is subtle, until the mouth begins to stick; then it should be necessary for him to thicken his food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	For it is the custom of assistance and the leg that they congeal within forty days; then therefore it should be loosed, and a bath administered, and it should be treated with ointments which correct that.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	But if the fracture is foul and crushed: then do not loosen from it a ligament and splints until fifty days, and even to two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	About the restoration of a fractured arm.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones which are called the two elbow-bones.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	Of which one is small and it is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And the other is large, and it is that which is placed under the small one from below.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps therefore the larger elbow-bone breaks alone or the smaller one, and perhaps both break together.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore the small upper elbow-bone breaks, then its restoration is easy, and its healing is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the lower elbow-bone breaks, it is a bad fracture, and its healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And worse than that is when both bones break together.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If therefore the bone that is fractured is a femur slightly above, then it befits the physician in its restoration, that he place a small splint with ease, until it fits.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If the bone that is fractured is a large femur: then it is necessary, that he place a stronger straitening.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And it is necessary, that he place the shape of the hand at its restoration, and its extended splint over a pillow.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be higher than all the fingers: and let the knuckles be lower than all the fingers, or the rest: and the invalid seated square over itself, and let a pillow be before him, or directly ahead of him, in height, so that the invalid does not incur hardship.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then let the servant extend the arm from the lower part, either by his hand or with a bandage.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And another servant extend similarly above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the physician makes the bone fit until he reduces it to its better shape as possible.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	Which if there are splinters in the fracture of a bone, then attempt to reduce all fragments into their place with your strength.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	If however it appears that there is a splinter separated and pierces the skin, and there is no hope of its restoration: then cut over it, and remove it according to the method which we said in those things which were mentioned beforehand.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	But if the fracture is with a wound, I have already done to that chapter alone, therefore receive its cure from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	But if a warm abscess occurs at the beginning of your restoration, then bind cloth with cerate made from rose oil and white wax, and let it be in the middle between thickness and subtlety: and tie the cloth tightly over it, until when the abscess is satiated: then remove the cerate and place a prepared plaster from flour of mills with egg white.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then place plates, and let a plate be placed over the fracture itself somewhat wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And know that the number of plates for the arm is six in most dispositions; whether the fracture be in one cubit, or in two cubits at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your plate tightly over the stronger and more grievous part of the fracture, and somewhat more to the upper or lower parts of it; or place a softer plate next to its own plate somewhat, according to what has been mentioned before at the beginning of this chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let the cloths that are wrapped over the fracture be soft, moist: and not hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let the thread with which it is tied be of pure linen properly, middle between fine and coarse, as we have narrated.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And consider the member and its ligaments after days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	But if something should happen which requires a correction, such as itching that occurs in the member: then you must embrocate the member with warmed water, until that itching ceases, and release the member not constricted, until it ceases, then repeat the binding.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	But if the bandage is now softened and the bone has been removed, and similar things have happened: then correct that whole thing with your own skill, and consider it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nourishment is prevented from reaching the member because of the excess of the bandage, then you must soften it somewhat and release it for a few days until nourishment flows to it, then bind it again.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if none of the things that we said should happen to a sick person occur, then it is not necessary for it to be untied, unless after twenty days or around these.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then let the hand of the patient be suspended from his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let his neck be level, and it is guarded by his own strength from sudden movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And make him sleep on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And know that this fracture is restored in thirty days, or in twenty-two days; and perhaps it is restored in eighteen days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	The whole of this is according to the dispositions of temperaments, and the dispositions of strength.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	On the restoration of fractures of the hand.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIII.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that a fracture of the wrist, and a fracture of the joints of the fingers occurs rarely.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not occur to him unless there is much rubbing against it.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When therefore a fracture of the sole, or attrition occurs; then it is necessary that the sick person sits square, and a seat be placed before him in accordance with equality.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand over it extended.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then the attendant should stretch out the fractured bones and the physician should join them together until they are joined with a good connection.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary that he places a plaster and a poultice, if there does not occur a hot abscess.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place a splint over it according to the size of the place; and now you have wrapped it up in linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	But if the fracture is near the lower part around the belly of the sole, then make a similar ball from cloth and instruct the patient to wrap it over with his fractured sole; then it should be tied up with a long cloth.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the splint be from leather, in which there is softness, so that the skin may stick to the body of the sole; and tie it as is necessary.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	But if the fracture is on the outside, then it is necessary that you place a splint over, and another splint from below on the sole; and the hand should be open and straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then place a bandage, as the hand turns; and stretch out between the fingers with a ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If a fracture should happen to some of the joints or fingers of the hand, then if it is the thumb, it will be set according to what is necessary.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then a splint should be placed with the sole of the foot: and if there is an arm, put to it a straight, small staff so that the fracture may be lifted and not be moved.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	But if the fracture is in the other fingers, such as the middle and index, or ear and ring fingers, then it should be set and bound with a sound finger that follows it; or all of them are bound according to their continuity: and it is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or place over it a small staff as we said about the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider in your treatment and after the aforementioned arrangement you will apply a hot poultice; and place with it as is necessary when something happens from it, according to how its narration is repeated.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	On the restoration of fractured hips.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone is often fractured and declared to sense because it turns to the inner and posterior part.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its restoration is done in such a way that a bandage is placed over the fracture and another bandage under the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the patient should be stretched out on his back.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then stretch out all the bandages to his side according to equality: and this, when there is a fracture in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	But if there is a fracture close to the root of the hip, then let the bandage be on the side of the thigh so that the extension falls upwards and another bandage under the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And thus similarly if there is a fracture close to the knee, then let the bandage be close to the knee so that the extension falls downwards.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician should set the bone with both his hands until he reduces it to its similarity of the natural shape and the bone is joined together with good conjunction.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then you should apply a poultice and bandage, if an abscess does not occur on the limb.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	But if it should happen to occur in him an abscess: then let you leave it for some days, until the warm abscess is settled, then return to your cure.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	Its stricture however be such.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	You must wrap over the fracture a piece of strong linen, that is to say, bind it; and double it twice, or thrice; and let there remain from it an excess.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then wrap the leg, until the heel comes at the root of the toes.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And insert a long thread between the thigh and leg near the knee to the lower parts, and let its ends come from the upper part of both parts.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then roll up over the leg and thigh that there is an excess from the linen.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then place on top of the thigh above the place of the fracture of it splints, and place from them one splint over the bone of the leg.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill in the vacancies between the leg and thigh with soft cloths, so that it matches the bandage.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin with the strong bandage from the middle over the place of the fracture three or four wrappings.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And as much as you stretch the bandage away from the place of the fracture, let your bandage be less tight and softer, and gentler.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then bring to the two ends of the thread that you inserted between the thigh and leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	So bind with them both three splints which are on top.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then go with the two ends of the thread to the lower parts, until you reach the sole of the foot.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And with both [ends] also tie together the ends of the splints from the other side, so that the bandage is not moved from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then let the bandage remain on it, as long as it remains, so that there is not a member corruption, nor an abscess, nor inflammation, and similar things.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	If something happens in it.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Then therefore apply the remedy to it, and correct that which has occurred from it, as we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	But if there is a piece of bone within a bone that pierces: then it is necessary for you to equalize it, if it is possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find something to place over it, and remove it; and take care of the one in whom this had previously occurred, until they are healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And when at times the fracture of the hip stiffens, aside from what is added to him with splints, as we said in aid and arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, in its restoration when thus fractured, lameness does not occur.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if it is restored alone, aside from what a leg is applied to him, then it is necessary for the one in whom it is, to limp always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And know that the hip stiffens in fifty days, or is added a little, or diminished a little; all this is according to the diversity of humors and other dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	About the restoration of the fracture of the patella of the knee.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	Know that a fracture of the patella of the knee rarely occurs, but attrition to it occurs many times.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	But if a fracture does occur to it, then only a fissure or a hole is found in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And it occurs with an injury and without an injury.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And a splint is placed over it entirely with feeling.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And its restoration is such that what has been disrupted from its parts with fingers will be equalized until it is gathered and joined, according to what is possible by adjustment and ease, and making.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then put a plaster made from sesame flour or mill dust with egg white on it; and place over it a round splint if you need one; and tie over it a suitable bandage.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the arrangements which we have narrated in other fractures: such as a suppurating boil, and similar ones: thus you must oppose to every occurrence what is suitable for it, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	On the restoration of a fractured leg.
Caput XVII.	Chapter Seventeen.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that the leg has two bones, one of which is thick and called by the name of the leg, and the other is thin and called the fibula.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And both of them are subject to the same kind of fracture that occurs in the two bones of the arm: and because of this their restoration is made similarly, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If both bones are broken at once, the leg becomes bent in all directions.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if the thinner bone is broken, the leg turns towards the front.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if the thicker bone is broken, you will find it lower down: and that one which does not hide itself from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then administer extension, and straightening, and binding of the thighs equally.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However it is necessary, if the fracture of the leg is a foul one with many soughings, that you make the extension less and the ease of treatment more gentle.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the leg indeed there is something of an operation similar to that on the arm: and it is, when you straighten the thighs and complete all your treatment, then take two splints made from the wood of pine, which are used in the construction of the sun-boards placed under tables: and they are made from the palms of hands: and choose among them those with a small thickness, and not small ones: and let their length be according to the length of the leg from the knee down.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then wrap each splint with two windings around it according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And place one part of the leg from one side and the other part from the opposite side: and they should be from the knee down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then bind two ligatures in three places from both ends and middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	For when the stricture is prevented, the crus turns to the right and left, and remains in good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And now indeed, a splint made of wood according to the length of the leg should be administered, and the leg placed in it, so that it may be conserved from movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And indeed it is very necessary to do this when there is a fracture with the wound proper.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then consider the leg every day, and study it with utmost care lest it become inflamed, or swollen, or for any other reason.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If therefore something happens from among them, then apply to it that which is necessary, until it heals, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	On the fracture of bones of the foot and fingers.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The heel indeed does not have a total fracture.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	However, bones of the foot indeed have a fracture sometimes, and fingers also little by little have a fracture: and there is no other cause for them but a bruise in many dispositions.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	But if a fracture occurs in the bones of the foot and you see those bones elevate themselves above each other, then let the patient place his foot on the prepared ground, as one walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand you and place your foot on that which is elevated from those bones: afterwards press upon it, or tread on it; and equalize it, until it returns to its places.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then place a plaster on top and a bandage over that: and place under the foot of the leg a small board with two flat heads.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind it to the foot properly, after you have wrapped it around with cloths and other things as is needed.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When therefore three days, or four, have passed for him, then loosen the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find bones that are equal (in size), whether they be broken or dislocated.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	Therefore the operation is as follows, which you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	But if some fingers are broken, then restore them and make equal just as I told you in the restoration of fingers on the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place a splint of your finger according to the length of the finger, and let it be slightly wider than that; then put this board under the foot which I told you about, and tie it with a decent tightness.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	But if what is broken consists of two or three bones, or more, then place over the entire finger a splint of its size, wrapped in linen cloth: and tie the board to the lower foot: and let it stand on one end of the board outside the belly of the foot, so that it may hold well in retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it is fitting for you to remember not to forget, that you should consider all the things which I have told you about other fractures from accidents as we mentioned them: and apply to every accident what is fitting with it.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	About a fracture of the vulva of a woman, and of the breastbone, and of the rib of man.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the vulva of a woman is broken, then make her sit with her legs spread apart.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then lean her towards the back side of herself a little and hold her tight in that way.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then the midwife should fill the vulva of hers with linen until it is full; and let it be like a sphere on the vulva.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then the woman is to be shaken, and her back lifted up little by little.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that linen cloth will come out until it becomes before the vulva like a sphere, and the broken bone returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a poultice on her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When therefore she wants to urinate, remove the cloth with ease, then let her urinate; and return it according to the manner in which you first placed it in: then she will go back to her first poultice.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	He should do that for seven days, or almost, because the jaw itself is restored.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you wish, take a bladder of a sheep, and tie a reed tube over its aperture, and insert the whole bladder into her vulva.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the tube with force, until the bladder swells within the vulva, for the fracture indeed returns.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then it will be filled with fat and stand for some days, according to what we have narrated, until it heals.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the jaw of a man or woman is fractured, then administer for its restoration, and for its equality that which we have narrated concerning bone Ancha.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And the straightening is not hidden in these nearby fractures that are slight, especially for him who has some knowledge or practice.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book thoroughly, because the fracture itself signifies to you in many dispositions the straight path for its restoration and constriction: understand therefore.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	In the thigh of a man when it is fractured, take the gut or neck of a goose: and insert the staff into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place over it a bandage of cloth, and it will be wrapped and left for three days, or nearly that many, and it will heal, if God wishes.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	Concerning the restoration of fractures of bones when they are with a wound.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is fitting for him who suffers a fracture with a wound, especially if it is great, such as the hip bone or similar ones, to hurry and bleed him immediately, if the conditions of bleeding are verified, as we have previously mentioned.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	But if the wound flows with blood, then you should hurry to its excision, so that you pulverize over it powdered cypress twig, if nothing else is present for you.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the fracture on that very same day; and do not put it off, if no suppurative swelling occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If, indeed, a hot suppurative swelling occurs, then put off the restoration until the ninth day, until the swelling subsides.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach it on the third and fourth days altogether, for you would cause bad things to occur to it.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	If the fractured bone is prominent above the skin and visible: then it is necessary to reduce it, and align it with your hands easily and with a small amount of extension.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If, however, its extension and alignment by hand do not prepare it: then reduce it with this tool.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And it is a tool made of iron, the length of which is seven or eight fingers, and its width is according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And on account of this it is necessary for the physician to take three or four from them according to the quantity which he needs for that cure in every kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And let it be rounded and let there be a small thickness in it so that it does not double on him under compression at the time of the operation: and let its end be sharp-edged.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And let its top be to the thickness from the middle of it up to the bottom.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	It is necessary in this operation that the sharp, curved end of it be placed over the extremity of the prominent bone: and push it with one force until the bone returns and is aligned in some equality.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Therefore attempt to align the ends of the fracture together.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	And if the ends of the fractured bone are thin and do not accept it with good reception, then it is necessary that you make a cut in the end of that bone, until the tool has power over it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	If indeed you cannot reduce them completely with what we have narrated, then cut it with the appropriate knife from the ones we mentioned: or saw it with a saw in any way possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then smooth out what remains on the bone from roughness and small shavings.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	Therefore when the bone is reduced and the patient finds a severe painful ache after the reduction of it, then you should know that the bone has not returned to its natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	Do therefore this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you are giving great help to the patient, since your completion of restoration to the bone is being done.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then soak a cloth in black vinegar wine.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And especially if it is summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place over the wound any cloth that has been ironed, nor anything that contains oil so that it does not cause putrefaction and corruption to occur.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then administer theriac in the hour that completes your restoration of the bone.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And leave the found wound: thus cut with pincers a hole in dressings according to the size of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And beware with all care lest you stitch the wound with a fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For often foolish doctors have done this and it has happened that they have caused their patients either death or corruption or gangrene, that is, foul discharge.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And let your stitch be soft, gentle, different from the stitches of other fractures remaining.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	But if the wound is bad, or a great wound, and you fear over it some evil accidents which we have narrated, and you find pain in the place suspended: then it is not necessary that you put theriac over it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make them bandages from strong cloths in the place of ointments, and bind it with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	When however a day or two have passed and you see the wound beginning to suppurate as it were with pus: then take away from above that cloth which you placed over it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then administer linseed and ointments with which we are accustomed to heal wounds, such as the four-herb unguent and similar ones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it is fitting for you to untie the bandage.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And look at the wound every day morning and evening until it heals and becomes solid.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it should be prepared so that liquid can flow from it downwards with ease.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	But if many days pass over the wound and it does not become solid nor is pus cut from it: then know that there are small splinters of bone there.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Therefore you must investigate the wound with a probe.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	But when as many of those splinters are separated, remove them and take out the rest.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And that which of them are not separated and cause the member to hurt and make pain occur, try to cut them and remove them in any way possible to you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	But if a burning or inflammation occurs in the wound, that is, an eschar or another kind of corruption and putrefaction: then you must apply to each of them with what suits it for cure, of which treatment was spoken about in its own chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from what I said that you must stand in, and to whom you make your present mind when the bone is broken and protrudes over the member, as the hip bone and supports and similar ones of great members: it is that you not dare to attract it, for often death results from it, nay rather leave it alone until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	For perhaps it will fall off by itself after twenty days or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then therefore treat the wound, if you wish; and if not, leave it.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	On the treatment of a knot (blood clot) at the site of a fracture.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	This knot often occurs at the site of healing of a fracture.
